title: News Notes for 2024-02-02
text:
Elon Musk pay package from Tesla denied by Delaware judge | AP News



Wages


Kind of an interesting idea - what if you took the hours he worked to figure out what his hourly rate was. It‚Äôs been 7521 days since July 1, 2003, the day Tesla incorporated. That means his work has been worth 7.312M dollars per day. A quick search shows Tesla‚Äôs revenue was 81Bn in 2022, about 221M per day. So his comp is just 3% of current daily revenue.
I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm missing something, like how much he‚Äôs been comped in the past. But 3% for making a company what it is doesn‚Äôt seem unreasonable. Of course, that‚Äôs not 3% on last year. That‚Äôs like 67% of 2022 revenue. Indeed that‚Äôs a lot.
Man, getting paid $7m per day is a lot of money. With $55M (assuming post tax) money he could buy literally every house in my town, at a premium of 50%. Imagine: a town called Elon. Or he could finally afford Twitter üßê.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: News Notes for 2024-01-19
text:
Social media platforms make $11B in ad revenue from U.S. teens ‚Äî Harvard Gazette

kids have always been targeted though. Don‚Äôt tell me the disease ridden McPlay place with its sad meals isn‚Äôt to blame too.
After reading The Quest for Cosmic Justice I‚Äôve considered how negative regulation can be. Let‚Äôs thought experiment: stop advertising to kids. Well then why not stop advertising to people of any other demographic? Old people are vulnerable too right? Okay so then let‚Äôs have free market. Advertise to anyone - okay let‚Äôs enable smoking ads again for kids. No that‚Äôs not good.


YouTube derived the greatest ad revenue from users 12 and under ($959.1 million), followed by Instagram ($801.1 million) and Facebook ($137.2 million). Instagram derived the greatest ad revenue from users ages 13-17 ($4 billion), followed by TikTok ($2 billion) and YouTube ($1.2 billion). The researchers also calculated that Snapchat derived the greatest share of its overall 2022 ad revenue from users under 18 (41 percent), followed by TikTok (35 percent), YouTube (27 percent), and Instagram (16 percent).

OpenAI announces first partnership with a university - education is going to be greatly commoditized. - Academic researchers can enjoy researching again instead of teaching (what some of them are horrid at) - I took an accounting class where half was online, half in person. This will be the future for all classes, but probably 10% in person. - The value of the professor will be in office hours.
Meta‚Äôs new goal is to build artificial general intelligence - The Verge

We‚Äôre used to there being pretty intense talent wars,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut there are different dynamics here with multiple companies going for the same profile, [and] a lot of VCs and folks throwing money at different projects, making it easy for people to start different things externally.


Big tech has the compute resources to develop AGi
Multiple AGI competition will increase security, lower cost.
We‚Äôll all have access eventually to open source AGI. And the same bad guys that have access will be countered by the good guys who have access. Just like today.

GitHub - FlagOpen/TACO - It‚Äôs good to have benchmarks everyone can rely on. Hopefully they don‚Äôt leak into the training data.

title: News Notes for 2024-01-23
text:
AI
Tesla finally releases FSD v12, its last hope for self-driving | Electrek - 300k rules based system down to a model - you‚Äôll need both: a model and overrides. - Or, you train the model by learning from the scenarios encoded in your 300k rules engine (like DeepMind‚Äôs AlphaGo)
Fast Tracking RAG Model Evaluation with Synthetic Data - synthetic data to evaluate RAG responses? - A response is non-deterministic, random - Perhaps do a Levenshtein distance of sorts to evaluate of response is as good as you want? - But isn‚Äôt this the same as question-answer pairs and instruction tuning?
Auto Wiki by Mutable.ai - this proves how powerful AI is. Just add data and watch it churn. - An example of an AI product.


Coding
Python Does Not Fully Deliver OOP Encapsulation Functionalities - I learned how attributes are names in a Python class. As an R programmer, most of these things were never taught to me in school, and I‚Äôve never really needed to know them (until working with software engineers)


Product
How Gong builds product - by Lenny Rachitsky - the planning!! > We do not plan monthly or biweekly. Both the engineering leader and I dislike the Scrum methodology. We feel it‚Äôs trying to drive urgency via artificial deadlines versus via value to the customer. And by forcing ‚Äúcommitment‚Äù to deliverables within a time window, it essentially inhibits on-the-fly trade-offs between content, quality, and timelines. Yet we have internal reviews with the different groups on a monthly basis.

title: Jesus the Christ. Chapter 35. Death and Burial
text:
The Jewish officials, who had not hesitated to slay their Lord, were horrified at the thought of men left hanging on crosses on such a day, for thereby the land would be defiled; so these scrupulous rulers went to Pilate and begged that Jesus and the two malefactors be summarily dispatched by the brutal Roman method of breaking their legs, the shock of which violent treatment had been found to be promptly fatal to the crucified. The governor gave his consent, and the soldiers broke the limbs of the two thieves with cudgels. Jesus, however, was found to be already dead, so they broke not His bones. Christ, the great Passover sacrifice, of whom all altar victims had been but suggestive prototypes, died through violence yet without a bone of His body being broken, as was a prescribed condition of the slain paschal lambs.

See Chapter 35. Death and Burial

title: Two worlds
text:
There are two worlds in starting this business:

I‚Äôm going to be wildly successful and be able to quit my FT job and buy a house on the beach
This is going to crumble in the next 20 days and I‚Äôm going to lose all my money and have to fire these people that I just hired. At any moment it could all just go poof.

There is no in between. It‚Äôs just a game of tennis. This is anxiety. I hope it doesn‚Äôt always have to be like this.
When I take a step back and look at the bigger picture though, this is what my last month has looked like (See below). It‚Äôs good to sit back and look.
I believe this is going to work out. I do. It will because it‚Äôs not some massive risk. It‚Äôs very small but sized opportunities. Each client is their own. There is no coordinated systemic risk. I‚Äôm not swinging for the fences. I just need a few bunts per month. If bunt 1 misses, it‚Äôs uncorrelated with bunt 2. They‚Äôll fall. People see the value. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs going to be a slog, but it‚Äôs also in my mind worth the hustle.

Dear team.
This week, the following has happened:

several audits for new customers (thanks @Adrian, @Sean)
Set up a few customers on GBP (thanks @Adrian!)
Had dozens of cold calls that are still waiting for me to call them! 5/5 of the people i‚Äôve talked to are interested. Great work @Guil!
@Sean joined us. he‚Äôs working on doing some cold calls and helping with some Local SEO audits. Welcome Sean!
No new deasl this week, Had several people say they‚Äôll pay next week. one cold call from @Guil , and two of my friends. Once this happens, we‚Äôre no longer losing money! (good for you - means you get more employment for years to come!) A lot of people are busy july 3-5 because of the holiday.
Built out a website http://www.precisionconcretebayarea.com from @Joshua Dumalag. Congrats Josh! A few more finishing touches and the customer will be really happy!
Made a pitch to a big apartment company. Hoping they close in the coming weeks.
@Lou Elton Evasco started working with our customer CGRE to help with ads.
@VeNae Rosdahl built our customer‚Äôs ads in Canva.
We launched http://docs.silvermineai.com/services and other websites to share out to customers.
We did a ton of behind-the-scenes work like onboarding flow @Mark Jayson Realino. just check asana for all the tasks Mark has put out!
Spoke with a dental group (2 locations) that wants us. The marketer is sold (wife of the husband dentist), she just needs to check with her team. This could be a ~2k/mo deal!

Housekeeping: - I paid most people as of the time of this post. if you haven‚Äôt been paid, check your DM‚Äôs.
Next week: - Goal: sign 2 deals out of 3-4 that are hopeful. None are more than 2 weeks old since Guil‚Äôs first cold call, it typically takes 3-4 fweeks to close. @Guil‚Äôs confident that within time a lot of these folks will
Team notes: - Thank you for all the work that you‚Äôre doing. As of June 7, none of you existed to me. Now we have 7 paid staff, 6 paying customers ($1515/mo MRR - all friends and family). This was an incredibly wild month. I honestly didn‚Äôt think this was really possible, but here we are. - I think we have our team - we‚Äôre ready to scale to Ads and Social media, and we have plenty of support on Local SEO work. We‚Äôll focus on growing our business for the next month. - I‚Äôm invested in helping each of you grow in your careers. Where there‚Äôs hard work, I recognize it! I‚Äôve already given 2 raises. I see what you put in! I want to support you and your families for years to come. - We‚Äôre all learning together. Thanks for your patience. I apologize if I‚Äôm not immediately responsive to every question. - When in doubt, take some actions and just let me know what you did! I doubt anyone is capable of messing anything up - you‚Äôre all really smart and experienced. I may ask for some revisions, but I don‚Äôt want to slow you down.
Let‚Äôs go!!



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: I can‚Äôt believe this is happening
text:
I‚Äôm at 5 customers. Paid customers. Money is coming into the bank. I can afford to hire people to do a job.
I‚Äôve never felt so overwhelmed. I like pause and just stare. What am I doing? How do I make good on these commitments?
I‚Äôm at $1290 in monthly revenue. I had two calls today that felt like they were going to change my life. Two real estate developers that want to flip homes and stuff apartment buildings. Those could get me higher.
So this is nuts. I‚Äôm feeling excited. Veronica is excited. She feels it happening.
How is this happening?

I just closed my neighbor. Gonna set him up with a website.
Charge for value. One booking all year will pay for the cost for him.
Wild. Just wild.

title: zoning out
text:
It‚Äôs been ~10 days since I posted on Facebook. This week I got four new leads. Tomorrow I have two pitches that could change my life forever.
Several times I just froze standing in the kitchen this week. Veronica asks ‚Äúyou okay‚Äù? Me: I just can‚Äôt believe this is happening.
Veronica: what do you need to do?
Me: everything.
V: one step at a time. Write it down. Hire people to help you.
Me: sends 3 job applications to the Philippines‚Ä¶
I paid someone $30 to figure out how I should pay him and the other team members. He provided me a solid recommendation. I felt relieved and followed his suggestion.

title: First cold customer
text:
Today we got our first customer from cold calling. It was a 45 minute call. Just explained what we do and the guy was interested. He kept asking more questions.
Now I feel some pressure. Gotta deliver. Gotta help out. But I‚Äôm excited to have a first customer fully onboard.
I‚Äôm okay to slow things down. To really focus on nailing the few customers I have. I don‚Äôt want to outstrip my ability to deliver. Little by little. Keep customers happy. Keep them coming.

title: Cold calling a cold caller
text:
A cold caller just asked me if I wanted to sell my house.
I said sure! For the right price.
Then that didn‚Äôt work out so I asked him if I could help him market his business. ‚ÄúWhat, you use AI? We‚Äôre trying to use that!‚Äù

title: Paying people
text:
One worker had to borrow $60 to pay for internet so he could cold call.
Yesterday his friend called him saying he needed the money to pay for his Internet.
I paid him on PayPal for his time, but his bank closed his account. So he needs to pick up cash.
Then another worker needed to pick up his $40. He‚Äôs trying to work two jobs at once.
How am I involved with these guys? They get fired at any time. No benefits. Constantly applying to work for whoever the Internet will hire. They do a few months and then they‚Äôre back and unemployed again. Sometimes for months.
I respect them. 

I found two guys who can help me with local SEO. I spent hours trying to set up different payment systems. I did some Kixie set up.
Tomorrow I‚Äôm going to build two proposals. I‚Äôm overdue. And I need to finish something for

title: Saturday
text:
It felt like a Sturdys but k was a Friday.
I had to let someone go today who wasn‚Äôt doing their job. I guess I was worried about it at the onset. I don‚Äôt want to hire someone who has red flags. It means you have to onboard them and people get used to them and then they have to go.
But is what it is. I ended up hiring someone who learned SEO from the person I let go. How did I know? They used the same template.
Still at 1515. Waiting for lots of deals to drop next week. Maybe mine will. I just need one more to stop losing money.
So many bits of minutia. Am I really going to keep doing this? i think so. It‚Äôs easy to just pour hours into though. Will it be worth my ROI? I don‚Äôt know. So far and a few hundred hours and I still haven‚Äôt gotten paid.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: 3 signed customers and perhaps 1-2 more coming this week
text:
I posted on Friday on Facebook that I‚Äôm starting a local SEO business. A few interesting things happened:

A coworker from an internship in 2012 reached out to me saying her company needs help with this. Meeting booked next Wednesday
A mentor from my youth reached out cryptically saying ‚Äúcall me if you want to tell me about what your doing‚Äù
A person said ‚Äúeverything you just wrote describes what I‚Äôm feeling‚Äù. Meeting booked Monday
My Filipino cold caller found someone who at least listened to me. 10% chance of going through is higher than 0%. My Filipino cost me $0 because he‚Äôs on a $300 commission (half of a whole months pay)
My own mother in law signed up. I hadn‚Äôt even thought of her.
I got maybe 2-4 other solid leads from things that could be a great match.

8 hours replying to each person who liked my post. I want to build a community - not just spam people. These 60 likes are my fans. People who like me enough to like it. Or like what I‚Äôm doing.
$390 in recurring revenue. If Monday drops I‚Äôm at maybe +$225. That‚Äôs $615. My phone center is $220/mo. My callers are free. My virtual assistant to help me is $500/mo. I‚Äôm a few hundred from breakeven. I still don‚Äôt even know how to make a Google business profile, the thing I‚Äôm selling.
But I understand what‚Äôs going on, so I can sell. I just haven‚Äôt done it yet.
But I‚Äôm gonna learn.
Takeaways:

10% chance of success > 0% chance. You miss 100% of the shots you don‚Äôt take. To build, put yourself in situations where you start off with a 10% but then get to the point of being able to be at 30% on the 20th try. Most of the time we prefer to be at 0% chance of success than 1%.
Quickest way to make money, and perhaps the only way, is to ask someone for it and offer them something more valuable to them in return. That‚Äôs it. If you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs more valuable to them than their money, just ask them.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Almost at first $1k
text:
Two weeks ago @James Lincoln asked me my offer. I laid out my offer and he just said ‚Äúyea you could do that but that offer doesn‚Äôt really work with agents and it‚Äôs a long sales cycle.‚Äù
It just woke me up. I‚Äôve been so on the fence about all of this TBH. It‚Äôs just so not me. I‚Äôm a corporate software guy‚Ä¶.
So I then pounded all the local SEO work last week and texted 5 friends. The wife of one of the friends signed up for $150. Then my fam member signed up for $120. Then I posted on Facebook.¬†
Another fam member saw my post who I‚Äôd just had dinner with the night before and was like ‚Äúhow did I not know you are doing this?‚Äù They signs up with their little business for $120.
My FB post offered $225 as an intro rate. I told my story. 70 people have liked it. I messaged each and every one.¬†
One person who liked it, didn‚Äôt know it was legit. She thought my FB account was hacked because I never post on FB. She‚Äôs a friend from 10 years ago. Haven‚Äôt spoken too since college. They‚Äôre a realtor.¬†
If they hadn‚Äôt liked and I hadn‚Äôt messaged then to thank me for liking, they never would have known this was a real thing, and perhaps it never would have been a real thing.
I sent my offer and today they signed up for $600/mo for Local SEO at $225 and local ads at $375/mo on Facebook. If they sell their house, they makes $15k. It‚Äôs a no brainer.¬†
Once they gives me their credit card they gives an audible sigh of relief, ‚ÄúBryan I know I just paid you $600 but I feel $6,000 of relief!! Can‚Äôt wait to have your help! Send me home work!‚Äù
I still have no idea what to do but here we go!¬†
ALL CAPS TIME. HUGE THANKS TO JAMES FOR MAKING DREAMS COME TRUE. i don‚Äôt know how you figured this all out with a job, kids, and an MBA. Hats OFFF. Let‚Äôs GOOOO!!!!!!!!



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Blogging with Quarto, and why I don‚Äôt use Medium anymore
text:
Been here before, eh?
I probably shouldn‚Äôt write this post considering I‚Äôve also written posts ‚Äúblogging with Jekyll‚Äù, ‚ÄúBlogdown‚Äù, and ‚Äúdistill‚Äù before. I‚Äôm flaky, what can I say. I‚Äôve changed my blogging framework 7 times in 5 years (I started with blogger.com and Wordpress before Jekyll, and even used Medium for 25 posts.)
But it‚Äôs not my fault. There are too many static site generators and it seems that Rstudio is as flaky as me. Meaning, they built rmarkdown, created hugodown, blowdown, bookdown, and distill. Hugodown is a lightweight version of blogdown, and I never figured out why it exists. Then there‚Äôs workflowr and so many other great, random products out there.
Why quarto for me? It seems to have all the stuff that distill has, and then some. And given its design and collaboration with Wes McKinney (pandas guy) in building quarto, and given that Wes wrote his latest book with it, I think this will be here to stay for at least 5 years.


Why do I avoid Medium
Why don‚Äôt I blog with Medium? I wrote 25 posts there over 9 months and loved it. It makes writing and publishing incredibly easy, which is why I did it. With distill/blogdown the limiting factor was I‚Äôd have to be at my computer to get a post in. I love writing on my phone - I have over 2000 journal entries with Day One over seven years, several of which are ‚Äúdraft‚Äù posts for a blog that won‚Äôt see the light of day since I don‚Äôt care about them after I‚Äôve written it. I want to be able to blog frequently, a short little blurb to keep up my writing, and medium enabled this.
But 1) I didn‚Äôt get many views (not that I care) and 2) my writing is stuck on their platform (confirmed to me this week as I‚Äôve tried several old, broken tools that attempt to export posts out of medium).
I got 50x the views on my blogdown site just from organic google searching. From reading other people‚Äôs posts about leaving Medium, it‚Äôs seems that most traffic to Medium posts comes from outside of Medium.
So while I‚Äôm certainly not into blogging for the money, I wouldn‚Äôt mind getting the content to people who it can help. And if medium didn‚Äôt enable this, what is its purpose?
So I‚Äôm back and finally decided that I‚Äôm going to own my own platform. Seth Godin wrote a blog about this topic once. Why be on Medium, substack, Facebook, etc or any other up an coming platform? We‚Äôll they‚Äôre all skewed toward the 1% of people who make money on the platform. Everyone else is wasting their time. So might as well own your content. And better to focus on writing than waste time catching up on every platform.
Also, it‚Äôs fun! There‚Äôs a fuzzy feeling to blogging.


Future of quarto?
I‚Äôm speculating here, but Quarto can be used withR Studio, Jupiter or VS Code. The last editor seems excitingly suspicious.
Perhaps R Studio sees the writing on the wall that VS Code is taking over the IDE world and perhaps taking over the long term future of R Studio IDE. I personally don‚Äôt see why anyone would pay for R Studio when VS Code is free and has a better interface. And while R Studio has a few better integrations for R at the moment, it won‚Äôt once enough people see the light for VS Code and turn their contributions there. I‚Äôve been using R on VSCode for two years now and it rivals R Studio in 95% of the feature set, but 100% has better window management.
So Quarto seems like a great opportunity for R Studio to begin monetizing on a publishing platform like R Studio connect. Platforms like Notion and Confluence are great for everyone except data scientists trying to share reproducible research. But a quarto server seems like a great way to finally bring in Python data scientists into the markdown-flavored documentation world. (Man, I personally can‚Äôt use Jupyter/Google colab notebooks when I can use R Markdown!) I‚Äôd heartedly welcome this prospect, though I have no idea what their plans for Quarto really are.
Till next blog post about what blogging tool I‚Äôm going to use‚Ä¶




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: What is a model?
text: _________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: What is a model?
section: I‚Äôm building a model, you know
text:
I‚Äôm building a model, you know
The first time I heard the word ‚Äúmodel‚Äù was from an engineering professor in college. I had no idea what he meant so I asked him. He looked at me like many who have forgotten their own ignorance and just said ‚ÄúSome calculations in excel. You know.‚Äù
No, you don‚Äôt know. But nod your head so you don‚Äôt look like an idiot. ‚ÄúRight, of course.‚Äù
Why this moment was intriguing to me is one of my personal mysteries. But it was one of those odd moments that stuck. I‚Äôm now here to help my old self make sense of the world.

title: What is a model?
section: The Same Name for Different Things
text:
The Same Name for Different Things
When I told my mom I build models for a living she shook her head. Turns out my dad had been telling her for years that he builds financial models, yet she never figured out exactly what it was that he did.
Let‚Äôs be clear on the common ground. A ‚Äúmodel‚Äù per the dictionary is ‚Äúsimplified description, especially a mathematical one, of a system or process, to assist calculations and predictions.‚Äù By this definition, my dad and I do the same thing. We use numbers to put structure on the world.

title: What is a model?
text:
Types of Models
A financial model is different than a statistical model is different than a physical model or a 3D architecture model. But they all do the same thing: use numbers to put structure on the world.
Every model has a few things in common: - They make assumptions about the world - They use data - They probably make some calculations to help someone make a decision
A financial model might make assumptions in a spreadsheet about how many customers you‚Äôll get per month for the next 12 months. This doesn‚Äôt seem complicated, and it shouldn‚Äôt: models don‚Äôt have to be complicated.
A data science model is one that might try to predict whether a customer is going to click on an ad.

title: What is a model?
text:
How does a model work?
The purpose of a math model is to imitate the ‚Äúdata-generating process‚Äù. Meaning, if you have some data on your customers (what they purchased and when), you would hope that there‚Äôs some rules that your customers are operating under. If you knew their income, their budget, their preferences, etc then you can guess how much they have to spend at a given time. Thus, if you know how much gas is in their tank, the mileage of the vehicle, the MPG of the vehicle, you can predict when they‚Äôll stop to fill up on a road tip. When they fill up, they generate some data. ‚ÄúBob purchased $34.52 of gas on Monday at 5:43pm.‚Äù Why did they purchase at that time of day? And why did they spend exactly $34.52?
If all you have outcome/results data then you can‚Äôt ever make predictions. But if you know what type of car Bob drives, how often he drives, how much gas he had in the morning when he left his house, etc, you can start to predict when he‚Äôll next fill up.
The assumption behind a model is that what was true in the past will remain true in the future.
Why have there been so many issues because of COVID? Nobody could have predicted a world wide pandemic. The world wasn‚Äôt the same. All the models stopped working. Supply chain models. Financial models. Default models. All of these assumptions across all industries started breaking down.

title: What is a model?
section: How do you build a data science model?
text:
How do you build a data science model?
Most people build models every time they calculate the ‚Äúmean‚Äù. This is the most ubiquitous model and anybody can use it. Sum your revenue and divide by number of purchases.
If you want to predict revenue for next Monday, just take the average revenue for every past Monday. That‚Äôs a model.
If Monday is a holiday or the Monday after Black Friday, your model might be very wrong. So you estimate black Friday‚Äôs sales by looking at last year‚Äôs sales. ‚ÄúLast Cyber Monday we sold 2x more than we typically do on a Monday. So I‚Äôll predict that on this upcoming Cyber Monday I‚Äôll do 2x more than what I did in the most recent Monday‚Äù
Now that you‚Äôre taking in some data, your building a model. You‚Äôre translating a theory on how the world works into numbers. You‚Äôre taking last year‚Äôs sales and using it to predict tomorrow‚Äôs sales.

title: What is a model?
text:
Start Simple
Whenever I build models, I always try to start simple and see if something more complicated can beat it.

Use averages
Build a rules-based model
Build a regression model/machine learning model
Build a ML model with rules on top of it

If I‚Äôm trying to predict whether a user will click an ad, the simplest model is ‚Äúwhat % of all users clicked this ad in the past?‚Äù If 20% of all users who see an ad click on it, then my ‚Äúmodel‚Äù is ‚Äúpredict a 20% chance of click‚Äù.
Then to make it more complicated, you can segment your users. ‚Äú10% of men click on this but 25% of women do.‚Äù You now have more data and better predictions.
A ‚Äúdecision tree‚Äù is a machine learning algorithm that just finds those segments in your data. ‚ÄúIf man age 30 in Chicago then 22.3% chance of clicking based on all past behavior of all 30-year old men in Chicago‚Äù. It‚Äôs called a decision tree because it will put every user into mutually exclusive groups.
Some ‚Äúbusiness logic‚Äù model might be making predictions around how your business operates. For example, if there‚Äôs a sale you may know that clicks increase.

title: When Leaders Lose their People
text:
In a scene in Dune, Paul notices that his warrior turns into his worshipper. He laments the loss, wondering if his non-religious warrior will be lost too.
Being a worshipped means you‚Äôre worshipped. Unchallenged. Can do no wrong. As such, you‚Äôre left with the intellect of one.
As a leader, you need to avoid worshippers. People who fail to challenge you out of fear or an abundance of praise. This all has to do in the decisions you make as a leader. The culture you decide to build. Is every voice heard, or does one voice rule them all?



One voice to rule them all

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Wirecutter reviewed the best todo list apps and declared ‚Äúticktick‚Äù the winner. After all my research here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned.
_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Structured
The highest rated app for planning on the App Store is ‚ÄúStructured‚Äù. Where this app excels is it‚Äôs simplicity. It‚Äôs likely best for someone like a student that wants to plan out when they‚Äôll get their homework done. What I loved about this app, and what I wish many others apps had, is a duration estimation for a task. Why is it so hard for developers to realize that tasks take time? They obsess over list keeping and app design but ignore the second most basic question: how long will this take? Structured kind of solves this. What I don‚Äôt like about this app is the design. While others praise it for its beauty and simplicity I thought the visual feel of it was distracting.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Microsoft To Do
Microsoft To Do used to be a favorite of mine. I loved its daily planner and smart suggestions. It has the philosophy that every day you should start fresh. All unfinished tasks will be removed from today and you‚Äôre left to pick and choose what you want to do. The fatal limitation however is that it lacks the ability to plan tomorrows a tasks the day before. So this forces people to have to populate their tasks at the start of the day. This is the worst time for planning for me because I want to get up and get going ASAP. (But honestly most times I wake up 15 minutes before my first meeting or am spending time pouring milk into my kids‚Äô cereal.) Morning is not the best time to plan a day for me, so I lost interest here.



To Do has smart text parsing.





To Do has ‚Äúsmart suggestions‚Äù that you can add to your day.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Todoist
I‚Äôve tried many times to get into Todoist. It has smart text parsing which is apparently best in class from my Reddit research.
Things it has:

Projects can have section labels. This lets you organize your list more meaningfully. This is great, only that TickTick does it better. Each project in TickTick can have subprojects. These subprojects act like sections. You can also move subproject from one list to another.


Things it lacks:

Can‚Äôt nest labels (tags)
Can‚Äôt create labels dynamically - you need to manually add them on the label screen before a task can leverage them.
Can‚Äôt pull in my calendar.
Doesn‚Äôt have check items, only subtasks.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Sorted3
This app takes a different design. It‚Äôs main selling point is the ability to auto schedule your day based on the tasks you have for that day.
Pros:

Rich formatting on description. Supports markdown.
clean UI. Good shortcuts.
integrates with calendar to plan your day.
Easily plan duration.

Really nice widgets.

Cons:

Doesn‚Äôt have subtasks, but has check boxes
No prioritization or smart filters. Just tags and lists.
Can‚Äôt easily see across lists like you can in TickTick

Auto schedule is nice but could be kind of gimmicky. If you have 8 meetings in a day and five 30 min free blocks but all your tasks for the day are an hour, it would put all your tasks at the end of the day. I found it kind of buggy.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Automated
Motion became popular as a calendar organizer. Add a task and Motion will figure out when to do that for you. If you change your meeting then Motion will adjust when your tasks will get done. Cons: it‚Äôs expensive ($20-$35 per month). It‚Äôs mobile app is horrid. It didn‚Äôt seem like it offered sub tasks and all that. So you really need to trust the algorithm.

It gets the notion of task-duration right. But if you want to jot down notes of all the next actions you need to take on a project, your up the creek. I‚Äôm also not sure how it handles task dependency - if I put in 5 tasks for a project will it know their order? Not sure. Again I‚Äôve never tried this app so take this all with a grain of salt.
Reclaim is another app claiming to do the same thing and offers a free tier. I did as much as set up my account with this.
Perhaps if I gave these more attention they‚Äôd prove their worth. I‚Äôve tried calendaring my todos in the past and it hasn‚Äôt been very effective for me. Perhaps these apps would solve it but I think I need a good mobile app.
Anyway, you can‚Äôt beat free and free is working for me on TickTick right now. Also, my calendar is very open generally so I don‚Äôt have the same problems a busy manager might have.
I think these apps would be best for people who have meeting heavy workflows. It handles the schedules as you need.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Akiflow
This app seemed expensive ($15/mo), no mobile app, but has an awesome calendar. The philosophy is you have to assign every task to a date and time to move it out of the inbox. That seemed like a headache to me, and seemed like I‚Äôd be constantly managing the inbox. That and I‚Äôm cheap and want a mobile app.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Sunsama
$20 per mo or $192/year. Super fast customer support.
Features: * Mobile app, Mac app. * Duration
Pros: * Channels (lists) * great shortcuts * can align tasks with objectives * more of a mindful daily planner * Integrates with Todoist and other apps. You can pull in all to foist metadata including subtasks and check them off in Sunsama. Additionally, you can add duration and calendar your Todoist tasks. * Can export all the tasks to csv. * Can split calendar events.
Cons: * Widgets are weak * No priority labels * No task tags/labels. (But you can use Todoist for this if you want.)

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Reclaim.ai
Task manager isn‚Äôt as good as Sunsama. Only $8/mo for pro. Has todoist integration too, but that‚Äôs a pro feature.
This is one I‚Äôll want to try later. It has the habit tracking and smart flexible calendaring. Not sure how good of a task manager it is. TBD.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Vimcal
Fast calendar. Not for tasks or backlogs it seems though. Didn‚Äôt try.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Asana
Oh man, how many times have I downloaded Asana? I started with it in 2014 and thought it was cool. Trying it again in 2022 it had a similar feel.
Asana is the only task manager app I reviewed that has dependency management. Sure, Jira has blockers and all that but Jiras more aimed toward high level project management. It‚Äôs not fast at the
Other things I remember liking:

infinite subtasks. This was fun and also distracting.
Automation features. You can create workflows for what happens to a task
Communication. It has a nice inbox feature that let me communicate with my manager easily.

Cons:

Clunky on the board management. If I want to start a new project things get messy and overwhelming.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Jira/GitHub projects
Great at a high level but messy to manage the gritty day to day. Doesn‚Äôt let you schedule or put due dates. So eventually I‚Äôd need some other tool to manage all the minutia of getting things done.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Not considered
I didn‚Äôt look at Things3 or OmniFocus, which are considered of the best tools. Things3 was too expensive and seemed like it had many of the same features as TickTick, except I personally didn‚Äôt like the UI.

title: New business Checklist
text:
Getting paid is easy. Getting paid the right way is harder.
You don‚Äôt need to have an LLC.

Get an address. You can use your own, but safer to pay $10/mo for a postal box. I use Ipostal.com
File an LLC. Use Incfile. Get it done right if you‚Äôre doing this business with a partner.
Using the EIN, go register a small business bank account. I chose Chase only because they do
Create a website.
Accounting software (Freshbooks)
On Freshbooks you can connect to strip. You need a website first.
Get an email provider. (Outlook or Google) You don‚Äôt need a website to do email, but you do need a domain. You can have anyone host your website, anyone register your name, and anyone do your email. But the company that registers your url will be the place where you manage your DNS records to set up your email.
Track your expenses separately. They‚Äôre all a tax write off.

Get a separate credit card, perhaps a small business credit card, for just this purpose.

title: The Allegory of the Dodo
text:
The scoop
There‚Äôs a great kids book, called ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a dodo on the wedding cake‚Äù.
So there‚Äôs this dodo, right, who walks in and hops on a cake. The attending violinist then scares it away and is praised for protecting the cake.
To the reader‚Äôs delight, more animals start appearing and the violinist excitedly protects the cake through hilarious misadventure. (My favorite is when he says, ‚Äúbegone beavers!‚Äù)
Two funny things happen though:

The guy soon realizes that all these creatures are wedding guests.
The guy has such a big nose and he‚Äôs allergic to marshmallows, that when he‚Äôs offered some cake he sneezes and the cake goes flying.




dodo on a cake




Morale?

When you praise someone for doing something good, they do it again and again. ‚Üí There‚Äôs a natural hero inside all of us.
But only the first animal was a problem. The beavers were the chefs. So he ends up creating all these problems thinking they‚Äôre problems. ‚Üí In tech, when you fix a bug you then think other things are bugs and go off fixing those too. No, just do the first. Then check in.
The irony is that, despite saving the cake, he sneezes and ruins the cake. ‚Üí Despite all the effort, the greatest protection to the cake was him staying away from it. Sometimes by trying to solve a problem we can make things way worse and create all these problems. (Politics? Create problems by creating solutions to problems that need solutions.)

Don‚Äôt mistake a beaver for a dodo. But don‚Äôt mistake a dodo for a wedding guest.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Resume Substance over Style
text:
Earlier in my career I got feedback from a prospective recruiter telling me my resume was ‚Äúvisually imbalanced‚Äù. Of course, the recruiter wanted my business.
But I went on to get over 70 interviews with that same template. I got a job at FAANG and a top startup using that resume template. I haven‚Äôt changed it.

Takeaway
How you write your resume and what‚Äôs on it will take you farther than how you design it.

title: Twas the Night before Christmas
text:
Link to the 1912 publication, Twas the Night Before Christmas
original poem was 1820‚Äôs
St Nick was 4th century
Dutch brought the name ‚ÄúSinterklass‚Äù to the U.S. in the 1600‚Äôs.
St Nick becomes red by 1931, thanks to Coke







The OG St.¬†Nick


Everything below is produced by GPT:
‚ÄúHow long has the concept of Santa been around? Where did‚Äùst nick‚Äù come from?‚Äù

The concept of Santa Claus has evolved over many centuries, originating from the historical figure of Saint Nicholas. Saint Nicholas was a 4th-century Christian bishop in Myra, which is now part of modern-day Turkey. He was known for his generosity and for performing miracles, which earned him a reputation as a protector of children and sailors.


The name ‚ÄúSanta Claus‚Äù evolved from the Dutch ‚ÄúSinterklaas,‚Äù a short form of Sint Nikolaas (Saint Nicholas). Dutch immigrants brought the traditions of Sinterklaas to America in the 17th and 18th centuries. In these traditions, Sinterklaas was depicted as a serious, religious figure who rewarded good children and punished the naughty ones.


During the 19th century, especially in America, the image of Santa Claus as we know it today began to take shape. The 1823 poem ‚ÄúA Visit from St.¬†Nicholas‚Äù (commonly known as ‚ÄúTwas the Night Before Christmas‚Äù) played a crucial role in shaping the modern character of Santa Claus, including his physical appearance and the tradition of delivering gifts to children.


Later, in the 19th and 20th centuries, Santa‚Äôs image was further popularized through various media, including advertisements, films, and songs, which contributed to the jovial, red-suited, and reindeer-driving character recognized globally today. This character represents a blend of the historical Saint Nicholas, folk traditions from various cultures, and modern commercial and media influences.

How did St Nick become red?

The transformation of Saint Nicholas into the red-suited Santa Claus is a gradual evolution influenced by cultural, artistic, and commercial factors. The image of Santa Claus wearing red clothes began to become popular in the 19th century, but it was solidified in the 20th century, particularly through advertising.



19th Century Literature and Art: In the 19th century, Santa Claus was often depicted in various colors of robes, including blue, green, and brown. However, by the latter half of the 19th century, the image of Santa in a red suit began to appear more frequently in literature and illustrations. Thomas Nast, a prominent American cartoonist, played a significant role in popularizing this image. In his illustrations for Harper‚Äôs Weekly starting in the 1860s, Nast depicted Santa Claus in a variety of outfits, including the now-familiar red suit.




Coca-Cola Advertising in the 20th Century: The standardized image of Santa Claus in a red suit with white fur trim was popularized and became iconic largely due to Coca-Cola advertising campaigns. In 1931, Coca-Cola commissioned illustrator Haddon Sundblom to create a Santa Claus for their Christmas advertising campaign. Sundblom‚Äôs Santa was jolly, rotund, and dressed in a red suit with white fur trim, which matched the company‚Äôs color scheme. These advertisements were widely circulated and became immensely popular, cementing the image of Santa Claus in a red suit in the public‚Äôs imagination.



While the red-suited Santa Claus is now ubiquitous, it‚Äôs important to note that the evolution of his image was influenced by a blend of historical, cultural, and commercial factors over several decades.

title: When data collection goes too far
text:
Self Surveillance
I came across this article in Flowing Data and thought it was fascinating.
I‚Äôve been on a productivity kick lately and notice these apps have habit trackers. I‚Äôve tried using them in the past and have realized it gets too much too quickly. But that doesn‚Äôt mean as a data guy that I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a cool idea. It just overwhelms me.
We‚Äôll I discovered that me tracking a few habits a day is junior varsity level. Felix‚Äôs blog is how it‚Äôs done to the extreme. Clearly this guy isn‚Äôt worried about Big Tech or Big Government harvesting his personal data. I love the boldness!
This is just 1/20th of the full page screen shot:

The number of slices and views he has is endless. It‚Äôs crazy to see everything he‚Äôs tracking, partly I‚Äôm sure because he has fun with it and the other part because he deep down hopes there‚Äôs something there.
His quote on Flowing Data has stuck with me:

Overall, having spent a significant amount of time building this project, scaling it up to the size it‚Äôs at now, as well as analysing the data, the main conclusion is that it is not worth building your own solution, and investing this much time. When I first started building this project 3 years ago, I expected to learn way more surprising and interesting facts. There were some, and it‚Äôs super interesting to look through those graphs, however retrospectively, it did not justify the hundreds of hours I invested in this project.

This guy probably knows himself in a way that none of us ever will. He can‚Äôt ever lie to himself and say ‚Äúyea, I‚Äôm good at exercising every day‚Äù because he‚Äôs got the data to back it up. But is this the life we want?


Self Surveillance as a Service
SSaaS? Apparently. Exist.io tries to find patterns in your personal data and tell you when your most happy.



Exist.io


When I researched the Apple Watch team a few years back I came to appreciate what they were/are trying to do: correlate heart monitoring with insurance claims data to proactively identify preemptive signs of cardiac arrest and other health issues.
That seems meaningful in theory because information about other people can be correlated with information about me.
But does info about myself correlate with info about myself? Probably. I have cycles. I have common traps and pitfalls like any human walking this earth. Some pitfalls are daily, some are quarterly or seasonal.
But I can also take 5 minutes to ponder reflectively or talk to a close friend and identify those patterns. What‚Äôs more human?
And what‚Äôs more: if you end up changing your behavior then your past can‚Äôt really predict your future. So all of the data becomes moot once it achieves its purpose: true lasting change. Because if you truly change your behavior based on the insights you glean about yourself, those past triggers and anomalies no longer affect you in the way they did. So when you experience a personal step change in life, you‚Äôre a new you. Maybe not. But maybe.
Also, the new generations growing up on smartphones have a unique challenge: their online identities are given to them before they‚Äôre really conscious enough to determine if that‚Äôs what they want to show the world. Parents posting YouTube or TikToks of their kids are cementing for these kids an identity they themselves didn‚Äôt choose. We‚Äôve all gone through phases of deleting Facebook photos from 15 years ago because it doesn‚Äôt reflect our current self image. What‚Äôs to be said of giving people an opportunity to change if everything they‚Äôve ever said or done is recorded somewhere? Twitter. Instagram. TikTok. Facebook. Every post is cementing us in a way.
I think it‚Äôs better to forget yesterday. Because it doesn‚Äôt have to have any bearing on where you‚Äôre going tomorrow. It can if you let it. But your past doesn‚Äôt have to define you.


Takeaways
Would you rather spend hours setting up digital automatic and manual tracking systems just to learn what you could by opening a gratitude journal every day? Sometimes less is more. I don‚Äôt think digital self surveillance is a direction we should go. (Not to mention the moment you do get hacked you‚Äôll deeply regret it.)
Even blogging can be dangerous for your career. Never know what‚Äôs gonna come back to haunt you years later.
So I should be careful what I say here, that is if I ever care to work for a self surveillance company in the future.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Decisions are Like Hopping on a River Raft
text:
I‚Äôm reading How to Decide: Simple Tools for Making Better Choices and thinking about decisions. I like to think of decisions as rivers.
Like decisions, all rivers lead somewhere. Where is your river heading?
The decision is which river to get on in your little boat. You can only envision the destination.
Being a high school English teacher is a decision. Where will that life take me after 5/10/20 years? Is that appealing? Only I can choose.
This thinking process is the decision choice. The rest is up to luck.



We‚Äôre all just Huck and Tom to some degree

title: This is an A/B test
text:
Dude. You‚Äôre being experimented on. Aren‚Äôt you a little bit curious how it works?
Bruh, they‚Äôre experimenting on you. Yes you. Now. Here‚Äôs how it works.
Im A/B testing out some clickbait, let‚Äôs see if it works üëáüëá
This post is not AI generated. I wrote it. But I‚Äôm testing an idea: what if I write and publish two posts at the exact same time but with different clickbait hooks? Same content (what I‚Äôm writing here.)
Hypothesis: I‚Äôm guessing LinkedIn will naturally favor one post over the other. Hard to know which.
A/B testing is all about this every day. Newspapers play with their bylines. Search engines play with their titles. Ad copy is all one massive experiment to see what clicks the most.
So drop a like if you like A/B tests. And keep an eye out for my other identical post, launched at 10am on Tuesday PST. Let‚Äôs see which gets the more impressions on LinkedIn!
Here are the two intros:
Dude. You‚Äôre being experimented on. Aren‚Äôt you a little bit curious how it works?
Bruh, they‚Äôre experimenting on you. Yes you. Now. Here‚Äôs how it works.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 2
text:
[Update 2021-11-16] This analysis was originally written on my old blog here. You can find the source code for it here.
This is part 2 out of a two-part series on scraping used car data. Check out part 1 to learn how to scrape the data.
_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 2
text:
You‚Äôre in the market
So you want to buy a car, but you don‚Äôt know anything about them? Welcome to my life.
You show up at the dealer and there‚Äôs a sticker on the window. You know the difference between make and model, but you soon learn what a trim is. Some versions come with leather. Some have a sun roof. Some have all wheel drive. Some have 20k in miles, and a similarly priced car in a higher trim is at 40k miles. How do you know what you‚Äôre really paying for, and what these features are worth? And how do you know what it‚Äôll be worth when it‚Äôs four years older and has an additional 40k miles?
Pretty advanced questions for someone who just learned what a powertrain is.
In this analysis, I‚Äôll dive into how you can use data to learn a lot about an industry in a short amount of time. I‚Äôll first dive into knowing what you‚Äôre buying (now and later). Then, I‚Äôll dive into how Truecar and others might be finding their ‚Äòdeals‚Äô.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 2
text:
What am I paying for?
To do any analysis, you need data. Please see my most recent post if you‚Äôre interested in learning how I got the data for this analysis. Suffice it to say, I webscraped it. The data is not my own, but belongs to Truecar.
I love using linear regression to understand my data on a granular level. In my data set, I was able to extract the make, model, year, mileage, trim, and a flag for whether the car was all wheel drive (awd == 1) or not. Putting this data into a linear regression, we can see some interesting results. First let‚Äôs look at the data we have:

library(dplyr)
load('../../data/used-car/tc-ford-edge.Rda')
# Get the prices into the appropriate scale and remove some extraneous
df$price = df$price*1000
df %>% select(-stats, -url, -int, -vin, -v6, -trueprice, -resid) %>% head()

##   price year mileage trim awd        location                   ext deal
## 1 16000 2014  28.477   SE   1    Sterling, VA                  <NA> 6514
## 2 13300 2013  64.315   SE   0   Chantilly, VA                  <NA> 1784
## 3 13800 2013  72.111  SEL   0     Fairfax, VA Mineral Gray Metallic 3331
## 4 16000 2014  27.490   SE   0    Manassas, VA          Oxford White 5448
## 5 12000 2013  66.825   SE   0 Clarksville, MD Mineral Gray Metallic   NA
## 6 14900 2014  65.157   SE   0    Manassas, VA Tuxedo Black Metallic 4436
##    mpyr
## 1  7.12
## 2 12.86
## 3 14.42
## 4  6.87
## 5 13.37
## 6 16.29
Now let‚Äôs see the regression results.

mod <- lm(price ~ as.factor(year) + mileage + trim + awd, data = df)
summary(mod)

## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = price ~ as.factor(year) + mileage + trim + awd, 
##     data = df)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -4755.7  -854.6    -2.7   877.5  5024.2 
## 
## Coefficients:
##                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)         22216.400    788.885  28.162  < 2e-16 ***
## as.factor(year)2013  1267.037    625.804   2.025   0.0442 *  
## as.factor(year)2014  3160.017    645.152   4.898 1.92e-06 ***
## as.factor(year)2015  5664.470    710.322   7.975 9.56e-14 ***
## as.factor(year)2016  6166.658    821.469   7.507 1.68e-12 ***
## as.factor(year)2017  9082.971    878.956  10.334  < 2e-16 ***
## mileage               -91.951      5.625 -16.347  < 2e-16 ***
## trimSE              -4983.725    409.765 -12.162  < 2e-16 ***
## trimSEL             -1822.889    291.400  -6.256 2.17e-09 ***
## trimSport            3419.270    374.977   9.119  < 2e-16 ***
## trimTitanium           99.242    568.428   0.175   0.8616    
## awd                  1277.734    222.680   5.738 3.30e-08 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 1450 on 211 degrees of freedom
