title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 1
text:
[Update 2021-11-16] This analysis was originally written on my old blog here. You can find the source code for it here. This code no longer works as TrueCar changed their CSS to make it more difficult to scrape. It‚Äôs still possible, but you‚Äôd need to build a custom scraper from scratch.
This is part 1 out of a two-part series on scraping used car data. Check out part 2 to learn how to analyze the data.
In another post, I describe how I use this data that I‚Äôve scraped, but I wanted to provide a more in-depth tutorial for those interested in how I got the data. Note, this data belongs to Truecar, so all uses herein are for personal and academic reasons only.
_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 1
text:
Get the data
In order to do any good analaysis, you first need data. I prefer to have more data than less, where possible. In this case, I don‚Äôt have any data, so I use webscraping to get the data. There are much better tutorials on how to scrape data, so I‚Äôll be light. I use R‚Äôs rvest package here, which does a decent job.1 Let‚Äôs look at Truecar‚Äôs Used Car postings2. First I use google to find the search query on Truecar that I like.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 1
text:
Load packages

library(rvest)
library(dplyr)
library(magrittr)
# Find the URL of the data you want to scrape
url <- 'https://www.truecar.com/used-cars-for-sale/listings/ford/edge/'
read_html(url)

## {xml_document}
## <html lang="en-US">
## [1] <head>\n<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset= ...
## [2] <body>\n    <!-- Element target for any partner code meant to execut ...
You‚Äôll see there‚Äôs a head and a body. Our data‚Äôs in the body, so let‚Äôs use html_nodes() and html_text() to parse out the data we want. I used Selectorgadget to know what HTML classes to search for.

read_html(url) %>% html_nodes('.col-xs-6.col-sm-8.no-left-padding') %>% html_text()

## character(0)
So that‚Äôs how you get the data on a single page. If you look closer at the URL, you see a lot of helpful things. First, there‚Äôs the make, then the model, then the location-zip, then the year-range, and ultimately the trim. This is a very pretty and clean URL. If you click on a few additional pages, you‚Äôll see the URL opens up with ?page=2.
https://www.truecar.com/used-cars-for-sale/listings/ford/edge/location-90210/?page=2
This is our ‚Äòin‚Äô to scraping multiple pages. I won‚Äôt bore you with the details of how to get that data into a neat matrix for us to analyze, but suffice it to say that I‚Äôm able to do it. Just build a function to construct a URL, and build a loop to go through the different pages, then use lots of str_extract() from the stringr package and gsub to clean up the data.

library(stringr)

make = 'ford'
model = 'edge'
zip = '90210'
year = 2012
npages = 5

url <- paste('https://www.truecar.com/used-cars-for-sale/listings/', 
             make, '/', 
             model ,
             '/location-', zip,
             '/year-',year,'-max/?page=', sep = "")

urls <- paste(url, 1:npages, sep = "")

scrape <- function(pageno){
  try(
    read_html(urls[pageno]) %>% html_nodes('.col-xs-6.col-sm-8.no-left-padding') %>% html_text()
  )
}

long_list = scrape(1)
for(i in 2:npages){
  print(i)
  new_list = try(scrape(i))
  
  error = ("try-error" %in% class(new_list))
  
  if( error == FALSE ){
    long_list = c(long_list, new_list) 
  } else {
    break
  }
}
## [1] 2
stats <- long_list
df <- as.data.frame(stats)
df$stats %<>% as.character()
df$price <- str_extract(df$stats, '\\$[0-9]*,[0-9]*') %>% 
  gsub('Price: |\\$|,', '', .) %>%
  as.numeric()
df$year <- str_extract(df$stats, '^[0-9]* ') %>% 
  as.numeric()
df$mileage <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Mileage: [0-9]*,[0-9]*') %>% 
  gsub('Mileage: |,', '', .) %>%
  as.numeric()

# a = df$stats[1]
df$trim <- str_extract(df$stats, '.*Mileage:') %>% 
  gsub('FWD|AWD|4x[24]|[24]WD|V6|4-cyl|^[0-9][0-9][0-9][0-9]|4dr|Automatic|Manual|Mileage:', '', ., ignore.case = T) %>% 
  gsub(make, '', ., ignore.case = T) %>% 
  gsub(model, '', ., ignore.case = T) %>% 
  trimws() 


df$awd <- grepl('AWD|4WD|4x4', df$stats, ignore.case = T) %>% as.numeric()
df$manual <- grepl('manual', df$stats) %>% as.numeric()
df$v6 <- grepl('V6', df$stats) %>% as.numeric()
df$location <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Location: .*Exterior:') %>% 
  gsub('Location: |Exterior:', '', .) %>% 
  trimws() 
df$ext <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Exterior: .*Interior:') %>% 
  gsub('Interior:|Exterior:', '', .) %>% 
  trimws() 
df$int <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Interior: .*VIN:') %>% 
  gsub('Interior: |VIN:', '', .) %>% 
  trimws() 
df$vin <- str_extract(df$stats, 'VIN: .*\\$') %>% 
  gsub('VIN: |\\$', '', .) %>% 
  substr(., 1, 17)
df$deal <- str_extract(df$stats, '\\$[0-9]*,[0-9]* below') %>% 
  gsub('below|\\$|,', '', .) %>% trimws() %>%
  as.numeric()

And here‚Äôs what the results look like. You‚Äôve got the original scraped data in the stats column and then everything else that you can parse out.

# df was the dataframe object we needed
df %>% select(-stats) %>% head(10) %>% formattable::formattable()

title: Writing a Tech Resume
text:
2024-04-14 update: this tweet is essential reading:


I applied to 100 jobs using a resume with the name, "Kismma D. Nhuhts" and I got 29 interviews. This is what I've learned about resumes: pic.twitter.com/MWuacsClFP

‚Äî Jerry Lee (@JerryJHLee) April 11, 2024










TL;DR: Use the ‚ÄúAccomplished [X] as measured by [Y] by doing [Z]‚Äù format.






Writing resume is painstaking, but let me help jumpstart you. My resume below has gotten me dozens of interviews with top tech companies (Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon, Microsoft, Waymo, LinkedIn, Hopper, etc).
It got me in the door, but let me be clear I didn‚Äôt pass most of those interviews üòù. That‚Äôs the point of the resume: open the door.
Let me help you get in the door.

My template
Here‚Äôs the google doc link to my resume template, also posted below.
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n8W79UBiWYhMWHeF4sNDtwaWxySRwU3t9isodbUuycI/view
You can copy this template and put in your own content.
I designed and wrote my resume the way I did by following the guidance of these resources:¬†

Blog: Google‚Äôs Accomplished X as measured by Y by doing Z formula
YouTube Video: Google‚Äôs How to write a resume
Blog: Cracking the Coding Interview: how to write a resume



Commentary

It takes some practice, but the XYZ formula is very powerful.
Emboldening words can be helpful to people who have 3 minutes to scan your resume.
I‚Äôve never gotten commentary on how long my resume is or crammed. I‚Äôm guessing people just glance for a few keywords and some decent content and assume the rest of the resume is good.
I‚Äôve had a lot of discussions in phone calls about my Personal Projects sections. Fellow techies all have their own personal projects and they want to know about mine. It sends a signal you‚Äôre intrinsically motivated.
While my resume is long-ish, I try to think: what story does this bullet point tell? What story am I trying to convey?



How can I Help?
I hope this helps! Send me a message at bryanwhitingcoaching@gmail.com if I can help review a resume or give more tips.

title: Water as a Currency?
text:
The book Dune is amazing in many ways, but the one that piqued my curiosity today was this: what if water was a currency?
The book gives great reverence to water, specifically talking about the lengths the Fremen go to to preserve their water. They even harvest it the dead, as water is life. They see people around them as water vessels. If you‚Äôre 100 kg (220lbs), they say you carry 60 kg of water weight. That‚Äôs a 60 liters. If you drink an average of 2 liters per day, that‚Äôs enough water to sustain you for 30 days. Fascinating how you would die without drinking water for a week though, right?
Some on this earth live with such water scarcity. Most in the US don‚Äôt. Consider what else we can focus on because we take the most life-giving substance for granted.



Water is precious

title: Better sweater
text:
I have this fleecy sweater jacket that is warm and cozy - until a 2 mph gust of wind hits it. Then all bets are off.
Made by a fancy outdoor apparel company, I expected more. That when they tested it they should have at least tested it‚Ä¶outside.
Then it dawned on me: there‚Äôs no wind in an office.
Well. There‚Äôs us one type of wind but it‚Äôs always 96 degrees.

title: New socks
text:
I once bought a pair of socks offering a lifetime warranty: if they ever rip or get a hole I can get a replacement!
I‚Äôm still trying to find them to see if they have any holes yet.
In the meantime I found a new solution: I take 6 pairs of random assortments of old puma socks from Costco. I wait in line for 3 hours to return them and then I get a new pack of 6.
Nothing better than a fresh pair of socks.

title: Personal Constitution
text:
Preamble
In the spirit of the book Principles, with a goal toward increased productivity through self-awareness and accountability, I cement here a personal constitution. I publish this publicly for all to read that I might benefit from their feedback.


Foundational Principles
Improvement through self awareness. As perhaps Socrates said, ‚Äúan unexamined life is not worth living‚Äù. To add my own twist: an examined life refines what‚Äôs worth living for. Like a chef with a fine palette, a self awareness acquired through reading, personal coaching, cognitive therapy, and above all journaling and hearing yourself talk, refines
Trust thyself: I can‚Äôt grow unless I test my opinions. ‚ÄúSuccess¬†in life is the¬†result of good judgment.¬†Good judgment¬†is usually the¬†result of experience.¬†Experience¬†is usually the¬†result of bad judgment.‚Äù Tony Robbins Alberto Savoia teaches in The Right It: Why So Many Ideas Fail and How to Make Sure Yours Succeeds the YODA framework - Your Own DAta. Only your own data is trustworthy. Intuition gets me to the point of knowing what data I need to collect. After intuition, there‚Äôs my opinion about what might happen, someone else‚Äôs opinion about what might happen, someone else‚Äôs data, and my own data. With limited time and the infeasability of collecting omniscient data (discussed in How to Decide: Simple Tools for Making Better Choices (Annie Duke)), I want to collect as much data as I can from other people‚Äôs mistakes by reading and learning. My value to the world, however, will come when I recognize that for a problem at hand that there is either data gathered via the Aristotlean methold of empirical evidence or Socratic method of reasoning by degrees. Judgment is used to determine whether data is worth being collected. In absence of data, ‚ÄúIf we have data, let‚Äôs look at data. If all we have are opinions, let‚Äôs go with mine.‚Äù Jim Barksdale, CEO of Netscape (Trustworthy Online Controlled Experiments: A Practical Guide to A/B Testing). I will be unafraid to share my opinion, even if perceived as stupid or wrong.
Assume Kindness, Give Kindness, Give and Seek Forgiveness. In a multi-cultural world, it‚Äôs hard to know what word might offend someone. I learned this by learning ‚ÄúHonduran‚Äù Spanish. The word for ‚ÄúWednesday‚Äù in one culture might be a curse word in another. Inadvertantly, if I‚Äôm to share an opinion with the best of intentions, I may offend someone unwittingly due to the way I shared it or the way they interpreted it. Everyone communicates differently. Assume kindness means to assume they don‚Äôt intend harm. Give kindness means to speak with good intention. Giving and seeking forgiveness is the process of recognizing that in assuming or giving kindness, I‚Äôll fall short but I can recover and let things go. Regardless of culture, we‚Äôre all human and want good feelings. We can operate in a way that cultivates these good feelings - a universal language.
Vulnerability is recognizing weakness, which is the foundation of true, enduring strength. As discussed in Dare to Lead and Overcoming the Five Dysfunctions of a Team, teams fail when they‚Äôre not vulnerable, vulnerable in the sense that they‚Äôre self aware to share their strengths and weaknesses and ask for help in their weaknesses. A toxic environment is one that fails to recognize weakness, because like a limp knee that causes first hip, then shoulder issues appear. A powerful Christian teaching states, ‚ÄúI¬†give¬†unto men weakness that they may be humble;‚Ä¶for if they humble themselves before me, and have faith in me, then will I make¬†weak¬†things become strong unto them.‚Äù (Ether 12:27). From this point of view, weakness is actually a gift. It‚Äôs a gift to rely on God (in my opinion, which is most often found in the goodness and grace of others) and ask for help. The Alcoholics Anonymous group recognizes the power of asking for help.


Principled Behaviors
Opinions deserve to be dissected, and everyone is filled with biases. Challenging Opinions: Put out opinions, and challenge others‚Äô: ‚ÄúStrong opinions, loosely held‚Äù is a mantra in tech and means something different to everyone. I interpret this as ‚Äúeveryone has an opinion, most choose to let the most dominant opinion run the conversation‚Äù. ‚Äústrong‚Äù means you recognize you actually do have an opinion, even if you don‚Äôt care. By sharing an opinion, you‚Äôre putting it out there to be challenged. Being willing to change it with new evidence is ‚Äúloosely-held‚Äù. It‚Äôs demonstrated in Elon Musk changing his opinion of how to design Starship while talking to a reporter. Speak, be open to challenges, and adjust. If I don‚Äôt challenge opinions, I‚Äôm at risk of ‚ÄúI told you so‚Äù syndrome later, except you didn‚Äôt tell them and instead you inflate your internal ego and did nothing to solve the problem.
Challenge theory, challenge data collection. As discussed in Scientific Freedom (Donald Braben), peer review is dying and failing the scientific process. As discussed in The Coddling of the American Mind (Jonathan Haidt,¬†Greg Lukianoff), cancel culture is crushing open and free discussion, opinions and movements usually driven by cognitive distortions. As demonstrated in The Quest for Cosmic Justice (Thomas Sowell), there is usually strong contra-evidence to very dogmatic political beliefs about ‚Äúhow things should be‚Äù. If we reason with evidence like Sowell, challenge our beliefs like Haidt/Lukianoff, and seek to establish real, empirical truth like Braben, we‚Äôll approach problems like Duke by considering all possibilitys, evaluating costs, and challenging internal biases. Data collection is difficult, and the procedures by which you collect data and draw conclusiosn from it must be challenged so that inferences can
If I have an issue I‚Äôll bring it to the problem first. If I have a conflict (see next section) with someone, I seek to resolve it behind closed doors first. It takes two people to resolve a conflict. If the conflict cannot be resolved behind closed doors, or repeatedly re-occurs despite my best efforts, I‚Äôll proceed to a more defensive stance, which often resolves in me processing it through journaling.
If I sense an issue, I seek to reassure those around me. I‚Äôve been in several great organizations, and several toxic organizations. Once, 2 weeks after joining a team I interviewed everyone on the team. I could tell immediately that 6/12 were incredibly dissatisfied even if they didn‚Äôt say it. One of them went so far as to tell me they hated their boss. Within a year, 5/12 had left the team to go somewhere else in the org. On another occassion, I joined a team and within one week of joining, one person asked me to unionize. Again, a lot of discord. Within 6 weeks 10 of the 20 data scientists in the company were fired, including the disgruntled. In a third cirucmstance, a lot of disgruntled employees foment amongst themselves, each trying to solve their problems with management. Management doesn‚Äôt recognize even direct requests for changes in behavior. In all three of these circumstances, I work quickly to bring up the issues. I speak directly with management. I speak in the first person, keeping confidences, and only doing so usually at my own personal risk. I try to resolve what I have experienced, and what I have control over. Sometimes, people don‚Äôt want to change. Usually this results in failed organizations, but not always. In all three of these circumstances, I have witness failed organizations. The first was in a large organization where the manager got a horrible ‚Äúdo not recommend‚Äù rating from their peers. The second was an organization that lost all of its remaining data science talent. The third was an organization that lost multiple long-tenured teammates, even key leaders, that went on to get top jobs at other top companies. Belief: if talent gets a great job at a great company elsewhere, the company is doing something wrong.


My Conflict Style
Conflict, to me, isn‚Äôt a dirty word if two people have good intentions. It becomes dirty when both parties have bad intentions. It‚Äôs at its worst when one has good intentions and the other has bad.
As the youngest child of peaceful parents, my conflict style is to observe and self-reflect.


How I‚Äôll Fail

After doing a ton of work on myself, I‚Äôve grown to an awareness of how I operate. There are past scars.

I‚Äôve been told I‚Äôm stupid before.
I‚Äôve been fired before. This leads
I hyperfocus on the negative.
I reason by extremes.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Writing is truly enlivening
text:
Hamilton is running out of time


I‚Äôve been writing for my whole life. I have at least 15-20 journals. I have 3000 notes in one app, 2200 notes in another, at least 1800 digital journal entries over 10 years, I‚Äôve built and replaced probably 5 blogs. This blog has 57 entries so far. What have I learned?

Make writing daily as easy as possible. I set up some automation so I can write from my phone for daily blogging.
Writing makes things feel real for me. It helps connect the dots. It‚Äôs a far more productive way to read the news. Less stuff, more thinking. Because if I can‚Äôt write at least one useful note about something I read, I realize it wasn‚Äôt worth reading.
Perhaps reading is the more important daily duty. Well, to write I need something to inspire me. Usually that comes from the news. Sometimes inspiration comes from yesterday‚Äôs post. This inspiration came from editing my prior post.

I‚Äôm not gonna worry about who reads this. But instead focus on writing every day because‚Ä¶

I think it helps me practice storytelling
helps me practice communication

Hamilton wrote like he was ‚Äúrunning out of time‚Äù. I‚Äôm writing because I want to use my time how I enjoy it.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: What is humanity
text:
AI and humanity


I code in cursor. I use ChatGPT when that fails. I see Pika and Runway for text to video. I see midjourney for photos. Other things that just use GPT to make blog posts.
Will AGI even solve the problem of getting everything to connect to everything?
Do we want a stochastic assistant to have access to my bank account, text messages, medical records, social media accounts, etc?
Will LLMs be the space between human communication? If we‚Äôre all using bots to generate material to send to each other, and all use bots to summarize that, then where will the real human connection exist?
We all want a world where our problems go away, but if we don‚Äôt have problems then are we human? To be naturally human is to be discontent and desire more, and it takes the wise to overcome these impulses. But the masses are not and never have been wise. Only the individuals.
The future is bright. But where does humanity fit into all of it?
When problems are too easy to solve with AI, humanity gets to focus even more on the really hard problems: agreeing on how to get along.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Reading this Daily
text:
#SundayThoughts Six weeks ago I stopped listening to podcasts in the morning and started listening to The Book of Mormon.
Perhaps this book doesn‚Äôt do it for you. If so, there are other scriptures or ancient philosophy texts that teach good principles. Meditations by Marcus Aurelius is a good one.
Listening to this timeless, ancient book every day has helped center me. It‚Äôs reminded me of God‚Äôs timetable. Of God‚Äôs intervention in the course of human nature. And of God‚Äôs unending love for us as His children.
How do I listen? I picked a theme: Revelation. I took notes every day on what the 10-30 minutes taught me about that theme. Now I‚Äôm working on the theme of ‚Äúpatience‚Äù.
Having this more-constant anchor in my life helps me remember what‚Äôs important each day. I feel a little bit more confidence and centered perspective each day I start with this practice.

title: How do you want to be remembered?
text:
On the sports fields of high school, I was often asked, ‚ÄúHow do you want to be remembered?‚Äù The energy behind that question is a rallying cry for someone to go out and score some goals and be victorious. Score goals ‚Üí be remembered forever in the annals of high school lore, the thinking goes.
This question misses the point.
In ‚ÄúEgo is the Enemy‚Äù, Ryan Holiday asks the rhetorical question ‚Äúto be or to do‚Äù. The mindset is that either we can focus on doing great work (spending time on action and education), or we can focus on being great (talking too much, dreaming too much). Ironically, greatness follows those who do, not those who say they will do.
So instead of asking ‚Äúhow will others remember me‚Äù, ask ‚Äúwhat will I do for others?‚Äù



Dan Kiefer via Unsplash


On this Christmas season, remember that while Jesus Christ‚Äôs divinity has been debated for centuries, certainly he‚Äôs been remembered. He‚Äôs been remembered because of the actions he took and the kindness he showed.
Christians believe he was the Son of God, one with literal power over death and rose from his own grave. He could calm the seas and turn water to wine. He was the rightful heir to the throne that his Roman captors sat on. He could have easily freed his oppressed nation to rest on his laurels forever.
Yet the recorded miracles we have from him don‚Äôt involve him showing moving mountains or collecting power and gold. The reason he‚Äôs remembered is because His miracles involve him spending time with individuals and in their service. He healed the sick. Caused the blind to see. He alleviated suffering.
May this Christmas be one where you don‚Äôt focus on what others think of you. May it be one where you enjoy following His example of doing good for others, however small.

Whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister; And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant: Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many. Matthew 20:26‚Äì28

Merry Christmas.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Junk attracts Junk
text:
Ever throw the shoes by the shoe rack? Or leave one dish in the sink? You know what happens: an avalanche.



All it takes is one bowl


Badly formatted code attracts more badly formatted code.
But the same is for good: a clean floor makes you want to keep it clean.
So what explains the fulcrum - where is the balance between accepting dire straights vs pushing for perfection? We oscillate between these worlds as our attention wanders.
I‚Äôm guessing the fulcrum is based on incentives. Guests coming over? Clean up the house. Boss reviewing? Clean the code.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Writing Only Makes Sense to the Author
text:
If you‚Äôre a bad author, your writing will only make sense to you.
Problem is, we‚Äôre all bad authors.
So when we write, we send out an idea. It then becomes a painting on the wall, up for anyone to interpret how they may.1 therefore, it‚Äôs best to put yourself as much in your audience‚Äôs shoes as possible (something discussed often in How to Win Friends and Influence People).

title: Writing Only Makes Sense to the Author
text: Going to an extreme - ever write a kind word that was taken as an insult, or sent something sarcastic and it was interpreted as literal?‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: 10 steps to optimize anything
text:
I love-hate goal setting. Here are 10 steps I often fail at in how I try to breakdown and achieve goals, but hey, this is LinkedIn so I‚Äôll share‚Ä¶

Objective: Define your ‚Äúwhere you are going‚Äù and your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù.
Principles: Decide what‚Äôs worth it in how you pursue your where/why.
Key Result: Measure the goal numerically 1-3 ways. Too many is too confusing.
KR-Drivers: Identify the key drivers that affect the goal.
Hypothesize: Use data/intuition to guess what will drive increases in KR-drivers.
Experiment: Try 2 approaches, manipulate the drivers in big or minor ways.
Track: Measure/track/Log what‚Äôs needed to measure if your hypothesis was valid or rejected.
Analyze: make minor tweaks in the drivers and measure statistically significant changes.
Conclude: Which direction will increase your KR. Consider alternate paths if the experiment didn‚Äôt yield good results.
Periodic Evaluation: At a pre-determined cadence (1 wk, 6 wk, quarter), choose if your KR is helping you achieve your objective.¬†

A few lessons learned as a professional experimenter:

Tracking is not the key result. Don‚Äôt confuse them. Too many people¬†¬†track habits for no reason (I‚Äôm guilty of this 100%)
KR‚Äôs have no purpose if you don‚Äôt have an objective. You want 100k ffollowers? 100k revenue? They don‚Äôt mean anything until you know what you‚Äôre going to do with it. More fame/money doesn‚Äôt equal more life satisfaction. Lots of unhappy/depressed rich/famous people.
‚ÄúExperimentation‚Äù early into defining a product should be massive swings. Find the ‚Äúlowest hanging fruit‚Äù, make the biggest changes.
Have principles to guide your KR‚Äôs. If you don‚Äôt
Have Anti-KR‚Äôs - things you won‚Äôt do. This is the hardest. If you have 10 KR‚Äôs, perhaps KR‚Äôs 2-10 should be all anti-KR‚Äôs. Otherwise, you‚Äôll get distracted on 2 despite you knowing 1 is most important.
A rising tide lifts all ships: By improving one KR, you may be sacrificing improving another. But more likely you‚Äôll actually improve all KR‚Äôs, because they‚Äôre usually correlated.

Easy Example: ‚ÄúI want to be healthier‚Äù

Objective: I want more energy to be able to devote it to my kids.
Principles:¬†
I will not hurt my body by doing unnecessary XYZ
I‚Äôm not going to kill myself. I‚Äôm going to keep this simple.
KR:¬†¬†(Write down 10, pick the one that will obviate the rest)
Gain 10 lbs of muscle
Eat 100g of protein a day
Sleep 8 hours a day
Meditate 20 minutes a day
KR-drivers for gaining 10 lbs of muscle:
Lift weights
Focus on quads
Focus on upper body
Hypothesize: If I go to the gym for 10 minutes for 28 days and do 30 exercises a day, I‚Äôll gain muscle.¬†
Experiment: I‚Äôll keep my diet the same - including the popcorn. I‚Äôll focus my mental energy on clearing my calendar and getting out the door to the gym. The ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù experiment is what I‚Äôve done the last 28 days‚Ä¶not worked out ü§£
Track:¬†

Day 1: I‚Äôll weight myself, write a journal about how I feel. Perhaps ask myself some questions.
Did I go to the gym for 10 minutes? I‚Äôll keep a piece of paper and a pen taped to my mirror or on my nightstand. Checkbox. Don‚Äôt track anything else. This is my one focus right now.

Analyze: on day 28, I‚Äôll weigh myself again.¬†
Conclude: Did this 28-day challenge change how I felt? Be honest: it might not. Perhaps I can get on my bike, or hike, or do pushups every day instead.
Periodic evaluation: every 2 months I‚Äôll investigate how my energy is.

your goal isn‚Äôt to gain/lose weight. Your goal is to feel better about your health. Your key result is a number on a scale going up/down.

title: Learn by doing
text:
TL;DR: Yes, unintelligent people can use things without fully understanding them








Many people have their noses up their ass when they claim you can't use an algorithm you don't fully understand.They give themselves this fake moral superiority. They must be the only ones who belong because they know every detail.This is all bullshit.Here are a few simple‚Ä¶

‚Äî Santiago (@svpino) December 12, 2023


While the language is perhaps a bit strong, I agree with the sentiment here.
I don‚Äôt have a PhD but have been limited twice in my career by those who wish I had one. What would having a PhD give you that I don‚Äôt have?
Well, I trust you more if you had one.
Jeremy Howard, a world renowned research and creator of fast.ai and answers.ai started his lectures on deep learning with ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt need to have a math degree, you just need to know a little bit of code‚Äù. With that philosophy he‚Äôs helped entrepreneurs create amazing products that left his free online program.

Blindspots tho
Concepts are important to understand. Understanding your training data and how the machines learn from them and the biases they‚Äôre prone to is very useful, perhaps mission critical, to creating value.
So what‚Äôs the line? Well, if you got a PhD you‚Äôd probably spend 80% of your time on your dissertation and taking some non relevant coursework. How does that help you today?
Well, you should learn as many concepts as you can. Like driving a car, you don‚Äôt need to know hydroplaning but you should learn hydroplaning. You don‚Äôt need to know how to drive in snow but you should know that driving a car in the snow with rear wheel drive is a different experience.
If you live in Arizona you don‚Äôt need to know how to drive in the snow. Your bias is you‚Äôll never know why that would be necessary.


Principle
Be so curious that you explore the boundaries of your space such that you learn ‚Äúoh, cars work differently in snow, but I don‚Äôt have snow so I‚Äôm safe‚Äù. Once you reach the boundary you probably know enough. Then ship your code and learn by how you messed things up.

title: Semantic Versioning for Data Science Models
text:
If you‚Äôve ever wanted to tag your data science model, you‚Äôve probably wondered how to version it. Which will it be: vx.4.1, v34.1231.51.21, or v91.x4.dev34? After reading about semantic versioning, I propose a method for versioning data science models.
_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Semantic Versioning for Data Science Models
text:
An Example
I build data science models by building python packages and committing the code to GitHub. The python package contains all of the support files and a main.py file to run the pipeline from start to finish. The support files could contain either helpful loggers to tell me where the pipeline is breaking down, diagnostic tools such as an AUC-ROC plot, files to engineer features, or files to train different model types. So there are really these three things that could happen to my code at any time. It doesn‚Äôt matter where those changes occur, or how many lines of code changed. What matters is what‚Äôs happened to the model. Each time I get a pull request approved, I‚Äôll update the version number in my repo.

Changing BETWEEN
Increment the BETWEEN version for the following changes:

When the structure of your data changes
If your target variable changes (how you coded it, or data that produced the target changed)
The underlying population you‚Äôre training on changes

Assume I discovered that I had a bad join. The join change might have been a minor one, but it‚Äôs now difficult to really compare the two models because my target was affected as a result. What I was predicting, even if slightly different, is now something different. If you ever feel like you‚Äôre comparing apples to oranges when looking at an AUC-ROC curve, update the BETWEEN version.
With each BETWEEN change, there should be a clear communication in the release notes of why the model is inherently different from prior models. These changes should be less frequent.


Changing WITHIN
Increment the WITHIN number when the following happens:

Features are added
Data sources are added or updated. (You might have several data sources today that help contribute to the target. But adding a data source might just mean adding new features. If you add data in such a way that it changes what you‚Äôre ultimately modeling, update the BETWEEN version.)
New modeling types are added. (You might be using a logistic regression, but add a mo)

So if I added files that allowed me to train different model types, or added files that engineered new features, I‚Äôd incrememnt the WITHIN version. In my mind, this shouldn‚Äôt be a count of features you include, but should just be incremented every time you do something that affects the model performance.
At any time, you might what to view different subsets of features and their effect on the model. So, you might not change the number of features, but add some functionality into your pipeline that now produces three different models in each run. I would increment the WITHIN version number in that case.
Remember, the goal of this type of versioning is to show generally what‚Äôs changed in your pipeline.


Changing PROCESS
Increment the PROCESS version when the following happens:

A minor bug is fixed (unless this updates BETWEEN or WITHIN)
Enhance a logger or aspect of the pipeline
Add a diagnostic plot or table

Basically, any time you add something that doesn‚Äôt ultimately affect the performance of the model, you should update the PROCESS version. Your changes might improve the flow of your code and make you a much happier developer, but if it doesn‚Äôt improve the model, then the key priority of your code hasn‚Äôt improved.

title: Future of Coding
text:
The Essence






TL;DR: The future belongs to those whom it‚Äôs always belonged






A blogger data scientist Santiago recently said on Twitter, (paraphrasing) ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to focus on what won‚Äôt change‚Äù. He was worried about how coding and AI will be automated, but Jeff Bezos wasn‚Äôt worried about so much of the world changing with the Internet. Bezos focused on what wasn‚Äôt changing.
This thought hit me, because I think it‚Äôs relevant to what our future looks like in 18 months.


Every day, a new winner
Nothings more apparent that the world is going to be wildly different than the past than to hop on X and see new academics one upping themselves with the next greatest LLM. Mistral just announced a 2Bn valuation as a 6 month old company. Fast is the new pace. And it‚Äôs oddly the case that big businesses are capable of massive disruption from upstarts. They can‚Äôt afford to stay glacial much longer (5-10 years).
With all of this, what about this blog post won‚Äôt change? Well, the timeless principle is that the nature of the game has changed permanently. Pandora‚Äôs box was opened.


The rise of a new equalizer
Go into a poor part of town and you‚Äôre guaranteed to see one thing: poor people using smart phones.
They have access to all the same information that the rich people have. The same excellent software. Same excellent hardware. All for a fee of $50/mo for the hardware and $25/mo for an unlimited data plan.
So that out the rich and the poor on the same level.
Well now, knowledge and reasoning is as accessible as Google Maps. You don‚Äôt have to pay $20/mo for ChatGPT plus. You can use Bing, Claude.ai, bard.google.com, You.com, or perplexity.ai for free. Now.
Sure people hate on bard and want to use the latest and greatest. But even the crappiest of the four I mentioned above (granted Bing/You.com use GPT in the background), is still leaps ahead of where we were just a year ago. If we were stuck only using one of these tools forever we‚Äôd still be massively more productive than not.
So knowledge and intellectual reasoning is going to be commonplace amongst the plebes.


if you value intelligence above all other human qualities, you‚Äôre gonna have a bad time

‚Äî Ilya Sutskever (@ilyasut) October 7, 2023




More of the same
So‚Ä¶what‚Äôs going to happen? Well, I‚Äôm not sure human nature will change much.
They say ‚Äúbeing rich doesn‚Äôt make you happier. It just makes you more of what you already were before being rich‚Äù.
And so, the mentally poor will remain so. They‚Äôll use AI for entertainment. Better video games. Better, faster content. More consumption.
The creatives will be more creative. Nobody will be at a barrier of being silo‚Äôd.¬†So what if you‚Äôve only done data science for 10 years. You know coding. It‚Äôs easy to now do web design. Or copy writing. Or art. Or‚Ä¶
And I won‚Äôt be able to stop the masses from using Code Interpreter to do data science. The systems will only become more powerful, so cloud companies will make it easier to write sql or whatever. Heck, 5-10 years English will be the only programming language. (Who here does firmware/bit mapping anymore? Only a select few.)


The hottest new programming language is English

‚Äî Andrej Karpathy (@karpathy) January 24, 2023


Python programmers will become like the engineers who create the seeds. And the rest of us just get bigger, better, and more efficient farms. There will always be those who specialize, as there are people who write compilers today, but fewer and farther between. Perhaps intellectual interest and economic incentives will equalize.


Festivus for the rest of us
Companies will become smaller. But the same human needs will need to be met:

food
shelter
clothes
physical toys
digital entertainment

More people will just be able to do more things. Perhaps there will be more prosperity as a result.
And more people will unionize and try to prevent the change. But that‚Äôs a short term thing. Can‚Äôt last forever. A union is only as good as it‚Äôs needed.


Takeaways
Get ahead by focusing on what‚Äôs essential. Leverage what‚Äôs around you to develop new skills to prepare for the future. And be excited. It‚Äôs going to be a wild ride.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Things I‚Äôd like in a blog
text:
quarto has strengths and drawbacks



Other frameworks (like Hugo) are more flexible. But quarto offers a lot more out of the box and handles the stuff I really don‚Äôt want to have to think about.





A traditional Quarto


Things quarto is good at:

Handles metadata really well (easy to get a title image, description, Twitter card, etc.)
heavily customizable: can organize posts as a list, as a table, as a grid, etc. can easily customize what‚Äôs in that. The main thing I didn‚Äôt like about Hugo was that the style was just slightly different than I liked it.
comments
searching
categories/tags
easy to create different/custom listings
can blog from my phone using Working Copy and GitHub actions

Things wish quarto were better at:

Faster render (Hugo speeds plz)
Don‚Äôt render future posts
A blog landing page that had a stream of entries, rather than just a list. (Similar to seths.blog)
Listings based on tags
make it easy to have an alternate slug (make all posts at root, and not in posts/)

Things I‚Äôd like to do with my blog:

generate weekly summaries
build some subscribers
send out a weekly summary of content.
auto-post to Twitter, Instagram (using photo + description + zapier) and Facebook.
auto-post anything with ‚ÄúLinkedIn‚Äù tag to LinkedIn
move editing into a vault in Obsidian
make it easier to copy ChatGPT photos to my blog post folder

For now, what it offers widely covers what it doesn‚Äôt. Most blog templates don‚Äôt allow for search, custom listings, lists of tags, Twitter content, etc. For now, quarto offers 95% of what I need.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Nothing to Lose
text:
There was a moment when I had everything to lose. When I was junior in high school, I was scared I‚Äôd be cut from the lacrosse team. There was only one coach and he didn‚Äôt have space for everybody. Coach held try outs.
My dad was traveling the week of try outs. I gave him a call. ‚ÄúWhat if I don‚Äôt make the team?‚Äù
He waits till I finish. And in a way characteristic of my Dad, he re-emphasizes the question. ‚ÄúWhat if? You go out there, you play your hardest, you give it your all. The rest is out of your hands. If you get cut, you get cut.‚Äù
He didn‚Äôt give me false praise or reassurance. He gave me perspective on life. He gave me ‚Äúnothing to lose.‚Äù
I never worked harder in my athletics than that week. I just didn‚Äôt want to get cut.
Well, I passed try outs. So did everyone else because it was just a coaching trick to motivate us‚Ä¶but that‚Äôs beside the point. But my dad‚Äôs advice was never lost on me.
I had low confidence the whole season. Yet my coach took a surprising interest in me. I got playing time as a junior. I was a part time defender.
Little did I know, nor could I ever have imagined as a defender who could barely pass or catch, that in my coach‚Äôs last game, I would be sitting on the wrong side of the field. I would be standing, as a defender, right in front of the opposing team‚Äôs goalie crease. I‚Äôm not quite sure how I got there as the whole season I always sprinted off the field whenever we transitioned from defense to offense.
My coach always yelled at me. ‚ÄúStay on the field!! It‚Äôs a fast break!‚Äù But I was always terrified of dropping the ball. I was great at defense. Great at scooping the ball. Great at passing it to an offender. This was my safe place.
Yet here I was, in the final minutes of the game. We had three, they had five. And I‚Äôm on the crease. What was I doing here?
My eyes and voice called to my teammate who saw me. My teammate who knew full well I had no intention of actually catching the ball. My teammate who would love to pass it to me if he had any assurance I‚Äôd actually catch it. I could see his eyes lock with mine and it only takes 8 years playing a sport to recognize that split-second glance, ‚ÄúAre you going to actually catch this?‚Äù My eyes asserted in that moment with my stick extended and ready ‚ÄúI really don‚Äôt know. But I‚Äôm wide open and I‚Äôm on the crease. And you have the defender and not me. So make a call.‚Äù
To my surprise he actually passed it. It didn‚Äôt have to be a just perfunctory vanity motion to please the coach. Because I‚Äôve called for the ball many times in that wrote script, ‚Äúoh please pass it I swear it‚Äôs worth all our time okay I did my thing now you guys go score because I‚Äôm outta here!‚Äù
I catch. I turn. I dunk. 4-5.
What just happened?
I asked Teddy later why he actually passed it to me. ‚ÄúI figured, what the heck? Maybe he‚Äôll catch it!!‚Äù We both laughed. He had nothing to lose.
I didn‚Äôt know it then, but it was the last goal anybody would score for my coach. It was the last game of the season. The last game of his 35 year career at our school. I was wholly undeserving.
And that‚Äôs when you stand most to gain.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: How to blog from your phone using quarto (or hugo/jekyll/etc) using Working Copy and Obsidian
text:
Here are the steps I use to post content from my phone to bryanwhiting.com.

Create a new, empty vault in Obsidian
Open working copy, set up synced repo. This means any changes are auto-synced.
Add remote, point it at your GitHub repo where your blog is
Set up a ‚Äúpull, stage, commit, push‚Äù shortcut
Set up GitHub actions to build, and push (use my repo‚Äôs workflow.yaml if you need an example)
Have GitHub pages (if your repo is private) or Netlify (if your repo is private, because you can‚Äôt have a private GitHub repo without paying)

And that‚Äôs it! Write markdown in obsidian. Push when you‚Äôre ready, let GitHub actions build and deploy. Check GitHub actions logs for any errors! (You‚Äôll get an email if it fails.)



Set up synced repo





Link the repo





_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: You can plan your life in 5 minutes
text:
It doesn‚Äôt take 30 years to plan a good life. It‚Äôs actually quite simple and if you sit down for 5 minutes you can figure out the following:

do you like where you‚Äôre at? Heading? No? Where do you want to go? Why? What do you need to change to get there?

That‚Äôs it.
No fancy grand vision. No elaborate planning. Just maybe 15 minutes to plan ahead.
The speed of planning is 0.01% of the effort required to execute. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to the moon by the end of the decade‚Äù. Plan. Done. Execution is hard.
Ideas are fleeting. Plans are changeable. Plans and ideas aren‚Äôt the IP of your company. It‚Äôs the people and the execution. Thats the hard part.



We‚Äôve been to the moon. Now let‚Äôs go to the sun.





_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Productivity
text:
Solid read: https://markmanson.net/attention-diet Over the last year I had read a few things similar to the points here and went on an ‚Äúlow information‚Äù diet (Tim Ferriss quote?).

I don‚Äôt miss the global news. It only got me angry.
The point of learning something is to take action and create positive change in the world. If I learn about things I don‚Äôt plan to take action on,
if that sounds uneducated, another reason to learn something is to gain empathy and change my perspective. However, the global news is generally biased by the wars for subscriptions between a handful of editors.
Niche news is far more educative. I‚Äôve subscribed to blogs, to specific influencers in my field, etc. I‚Äôve learned things from these people that I can apply that day in my job. I‚Äôm subscribing to things that feed my career.
long form content is far better way to understand current events. If you want to understand the state of the world, read a book on it. Most major geopolitical events are insanely complicated and cannot be surmised in 126 characters. Read a few books on the things you care about.
there‚Äôs so much thought put into even a low quality book. Think about it: most books get reviewed by editors in the very least. They probably get read once or twice at least by the original authors. So what would be a better time for your energy - a low quality book or a set of posts on LinkedIn likely generated by ChatGPT or Jasper.ai? If a low quality book > than a tweet, surely 30 min a day of a high quality book (easy to find) is worth more than most low quality content.
I broke my iPhone in 2020 and waited 45 days for a replacement. But it wasn‚Äôt fully broken - the screen was hopelessly shattered on the bottom half where typing is required. So I kept it in my drawer and only used it when I needed to. The risk of using it? Getting a shard of glass stuck in my finger. I wish I still had that to some degree because it forced me to be focused. I realized very few people texted me anything urgent that couldn‚Äôt wait a few days. I could still call people with Siri, but nobody called. We‚Äôre optimized to be addicted. That‚Äôs literally the goal of these phones and the apps on them. That‚Äôs not a bad thing. It‚Äôs just not in our best interest.
I tried using a junk $40 replacement phone I found in my closet while waiting those 45 days to get my iPhone replacement. The phone was from 2015 when I got married - it was a teaser phone from the cell company. It probably downloaded at 2 mbp/s. Any time I clicked a link I had to wait 15-20 seconds for the page to load.

I was amazed. I was shocked this piece of junk actually could take notes. Could email. Could browse the internet. But I also learned not to click on things unless it was worth 30 seconds of my time.
How do I spend my time now? Not wisely enough. A lot of things should be done on a computer. Most things should be planned. Few things are urgent. Fewer are essential.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: The Iceberg Theory - Theory of Omission
text:
Hemingway introduced through his writing style the Iceberg Theory. It was something I noticed while reading The Old Man and the Sea. You feel the depth of emotion from the ‚Äúactions and dialogue‚Äù, rather than explicit descriptions.
It‚Äôs fun to contrast that with Frank Herbert‚Äôs style which is ‚Äúlay out the environment, have dialogue, then draw conclusions in the mind‚Äù.
Both styles speak to the thought that the writing is more interesting the less you write about. They call this ‚Äúnegative space‚Äù in drawing. A sketch is interesting when the mind can fill in the gaps. As an artist, you just want to make enough dots that they can connect them themselves. This connecting process is the freedom and interest the mind craves. It doesn‚Äôt want to be coddled (The Coddling of the American Mind).
Back to the book. The Old Man and the Sea can be summarized in one sentence: a tired, old, and recently-unlucky man catches the biggest of his life and it gets eaten before he makes it home.
That‚Äôs the surface story, and it‚Äôs rather boring when thought of that way. But you just feel so much while reading it. You feel for the old man through the young boy. You feel for him as he teeters between passing out and existing. You remember the breaking points in your own life and want the man desperately to succeed. Luck, however, was not on his side.
‚ÄúTalk less. Smile more.‚Äù - Hamilton



Let their mind wander

title: Flipping the coins of life
text:
Assume you flip a coin 5 times and get heads 5 times. You‚Äôre going pretty well!
But are you?
A normal coin has 50% chance of heads. Chances of 5 heads in a row is ~3/100. It‚Äôs not nothing. But over time this will average to 50%, if you flip 10000 times.
Decisions are rarely black and whites despite how we choice to say ‚Äúthat was a bad decision‚Äù. The outcome doesn‚Äôt determine the quality of the decision.
You chose to flip a coin, and not roll a dice. You didn‚Äôt roll a 32 sided die either.
Focus on choice that maximize probability. This is the decision.

how-to-decide-simple-tools-for-making-better-choices
decisions-are-rivers

title: New ideas are distractingly exciting
text:
When a new idea comes to my mind, I want to act on it right away. Perhaps it‚Äôs an exciting analysis idea, a new business strategy I want to scope out, or a question to ask a team member.
But as I look back at my backlog of things to work on, all of these ideas were also equally exciting.
Why is it that new ideas have more weight than old ideas?
They say that effectiveness is working quickly on tasks. Efficiency is knowing what to work on. Discipline is the ability to overcome the excitement of a new idea and place it in proper context of all ideas. Sanity is actively saying no to many ideas so you don‚Äôt get inundated.
Perhaps a good strategy is to have a ‚Äúgut check‚Äù for ideas. If they don‚Äôt pass the highest threshold then let them go.
Process:

What‚Äôs the new idea?
What‚Äôs the potential impact? What would I do with the output of this idea?
How feasible is it?

Step 3 is tricky because I don‚Äôt want a good idea to go to waste just because it‚Äôs hard. Judgment is weighing the trade off between impact and feasibility.
I like Google Forms for logging ideas. It‚Äôs easy to save a Google Form URL to the home screen of my iPhone to make logging new ideas easy. Grooming those ideas is important. Letting go of old ideas is essential. If only I could do the essential‚Ä¶

title: The Multiverse of Careers
text:
Spoken about in The Dream State of Software, Paul of Dune has a moment where he‚Äôs both past and present in his mind. He doesn‚Äôt know even whether he‚Äôs had his kid or not.
In a podcast I listened to lately on happiness, one suggestion was to write out all your goals and cross them off from day one. Pretend like it doesn‚Äôt even matter if you accomplish them. This helps free you.
Careers are like both of these things. We want everything. We can pretend like we have it. We can come to terms with it. And we can say ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt matter if I don‚Äôt get that, because I‚Äôve got a life outside my career.‚Äù



Which path you choose isn‚Äôt as important as who you choose as companions


Consider your career from your deathbed (My Tombstone). What path did you take that mattered? What were all the alternate realities and multiverses you could have had.
Put them all together. In one multiverse you‚Äôve been fired. In another you end up getting insanely wealthy. In another you start your own company. In another you become an online blogger.
All of them can‚Äôt be true when you do this exercise extensively enough. And choosing which one probably doesn‚Äôt matter as much (right vs wrong path thinking). If you‚Äôve ever left a job you realize that nothing really comes over with you. Most relationships at work are short lived and contextual, like your relationships in high school. And that‚Äôs life.
Happiness is perhaps being okay with not having everything you desire, except for the few things that are truly attainable: peace with God, self, and cherished relationships.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: 97 percent chance you‚Äôll fail
text:
In Flipping the coins of life, I outline how you can succeed 5 times with a success rate of 3%. That also means you have a 97% chance you won‚Äôt succeed 5 times in a row.



Flipping five coins will almost certainly yield at least tails


In life, we sometimes overemphasize winning. Even in the tech world of wanting to fail fast, I think most people just really want to win every time. Nobody seeks failure - that‚Äôs not the goal. They seek other things (learning, promotions, making more money).
When making decisions, it‚Äôs easy to black-and-white them. If there‚Äôs only a 3% change we‚Äôll win 5 times in a row (with a 50% chance of winning every time), there‚Äôs a 97% chance you‚Äôll fail at least once every 5 attempts.
If your probability of success is lower, then the odds of failing at once in five are almost 100%.
How do you quantify a life decision though? Maybe you only get one big choice a year (job change, like as is discussed in How to Decide: Simple Tools for Making Better Choices). Is there a 50% chance of ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù? If so, every five years you‚Äôre highly likely to ‚Äúfail‚Äù.
Per the book, it‚Äôs more likely that one bad thing happens and we hindsight bias our decision and black-and-white it.
Reality is: getting fired or your startup blowing up might be the best thing that ever happens to you. You just don‚Äôt know. Your story isn‚Äôt written yet. And actually, it‚Äôs not so much about if you made the right choice as if you just make the choice right in some way.
Choose your love, and then love your choice, as they say.

title: The Power of Party Pay by Visible
text:
Visible‚Äôs party pay madness
Visible wireless offers $25 off to users who join a party. So a user who signs up to pay $50 for unlimited data can click one button to join a party and only have to pay $25/mo from then on. Why not just offer users $25 to begin with?
It‚Äôs really confusing to me as a user - why not just give me the $25 automatically if it takes nothing to join a group? Because of gamification.


Why it works
I think their strategy is as follows:

They hope some people get brought in on marketing and never remember to activate a party pay. Let‚Äôs say this number is 20-40%. Perhaps these users fund the rest of the discounts.
Joining a party pay group for free is an easy way to make your customers win. I.e., a user gets $25 off for joining. Gimmicky, but I think it works. So a user has an immediate sense of gratification - a great way to build a strong emotional bond. ‚ÄúClick a button to get $25 off in perpetuity? Nice!‚Äù Anyone would agree this feels better than just starting off with $25.
This makes users want to share and tell others. Especially if customers feel they‚Äôve gamed the system. Who today doesn‚Äôt like a hack?

But even if (1) is wrong, and that 95% of people join a party I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôve done the math to consider how many people they need to sign up to make the money work.


The Larger Strategy
Why would Verizon cannibalize their own sales? I switched my wife out of a $70 unlimited plan on Verizon to a $25 plan on visible for the same service. Well some customers will stay with Verizon because of its prestige and the add on benefits. But users who are cutting the cord are going somewhere else, I‚Äôm thinking Verizon wants to stay ahead of the curve. It‚Äôs a race to the bottom, sure. But it doesn‚Äôt hurt to try to win the race.

title: The DataViz battle: Plotly vs ggplot2
text:
R users fall in love with ggplot2, the growing standard for data visualization in R. The ability to quickly vizualize trends, and customize just about anything you‚Äôd want, make it a powerful tool. Yet this week, I made a discovery that may reduce how much I used ggplot2. Enter plot_ly().
For this post, I assume that you have a working knowledge of the dplyr (or magrittr) and ggplot2 packages. I caveat that this post is backed with only 4-5 hours using plotly(), so some statements here may not be fully vetted.
Plotly and ggplot2 are inherently for different purposes. plotly allows you to quickly create beautiful, reactive D3 plots that are particularly powerful in websites and dashboards. You can hover your mouse over the plots and see the data values, zoom in and out of specific regions, and capture stills. Here‚Äôs a basic histogram:
set.seed(1)
library(plotly)
plot_ly(x = ~ rnorm(1000), type = "histogram")
After a brief dabble this week in plotly, I realized quickly the many advantages that plotly has over ggplot2.
Several initial impressions:
Benefits of ggplot2 over plotly:

title: How to Sign in with iCloud Calendar on Outlook for iOS
text:
How do I add an iCloud account to iOS Outlook without it being a public calendar?
It was easy to add any gmail accounts but I didn‚Äôt know how to add my iCloud calendar to iOS Outlook. Part of the issue is my iCloud account is actually my gmail email address so I can‚Äôt sign in with this or it‚Äôll load my gmail calendar.
Solution:

go to iOS settings > iCloud > get your @icloud.com name. If you use your gmail account for iCloud there‚Äôs still this @icloud account.
Attempt to log into iOS Outlook calendar. Apple will then make you create an app-specific password for iOS Outlook
Use this password.

Done. Pain solved.

title: 30 Seconds is All You Get
text:
Apple iTunes changed the music industry forever with one simple decision: the preview of a song should be 30 seconds long.
This little change dramatically altered how music sounds today. I‚Äôve recently listened to some bangers that were only 90 seconds long. They left me hanging.



Enjoy the music while it lasts


Why was my song so short? Because nobody gets paid after 30 seconds.

Apple‚Äôs decision made artists want to have more interesting 30 seconds in the iTunes Store
That evolved into: an artist doesn‚Äôt get paid if you don‚Äôt listen at least 30 seconds. And they don‚Äôt get paid any more if you listen 31 or 900 seconds. In fact, they get paid more if you listen to two songs, 30s a piece.

Spotify, Amazon, YouTube, Apple, etc all pay based on views. They each define views their own way, but they need to negotiate with the labels who already decided to agree to Apple‚Äôs 30s schemes in the early 2000‚Äôs. They may have different payment schemes, but some have a scheme of ‚Äútake all revenue, distribute it according to the artist‚Äôs share of views.‚Äù So if I pay $10/mo for Spotify and don‚Äôt use it, my money goes to someone I didn‚Äôt listen to.
So how do small artists compete? They‚Äôve got to build their following. Proportionally, the major artists (rather, their labels) soak up all the streaming royalties.
What would be more fair is if my $10 went to the artists I actually listened to, as if I bought their music.
Why does any of this matter? Algorithms. Optimization. Monetization.
Incentives drive outcomes. How we designed our music payment incentives altered music forever (try to be super catchy for 30s). Now, with AI, music can be created much faster which will dilute the pool.
In the end, one simple decision changed billions of lives. 30s? That‚Äôs all you need to get paid.

title: Pomodoro Principles
text:
I‚Äôve been trying a Pomodoro timer in TickTick and it‚Äôs changing how I approach my work day. I‚Äôve been using it for two days so far and here are the differences I notice:

When my mind knows I‚Äôll get a break at 25 minutes, it allows me to focus more.
It‚Äôs easier to say not to slack messages or impulses to open the news if I know I‚Äôll have time for those things later.
A 5 min break is perfect.
If a distraction pops up, I write it down in my journal and tell myself I can follow up during my break.
25 minutes is short. It‚Äôs amazing how time flies.

I used to hate timing myself after working in consulting. I vowed I would never work on the clock ever again. But don‚Äôt the best athletes pace themselves? Any marathon trainer knows how to set a pace and have rest periods. Why wouldn‚Äôt the same principles apply to cognitive work?

title: Downstream Impact
text:
Every pea is unique. But it‚Äôs still a pea.


Online experiments are powerful tools to see the causal impact of a business strategy. Tweak something, see what users do.
The limitations of online experiments is that once you manipulate your user experience there‚Äôs no going back. Users are forever impacted by your choice.
If you give out a credit card with $100, $300, and $500 lines, people are going to spend more on the $500 line. They might also default more because they‚Äôre less able to pay back $500 than they are $100. As a result, you may lose these $500 users forever and might impact other aspects of their life, not to mention impact the marketing department‚Äôs strategy.
A group of users is like a single living organism, if you treat it like that. If you only measure one metric (conversion rate) on the entire massive audience, then you‚Äôll optimize for the ‚Äúaverage‚Äù user.
But nobody is average. We are all distinct. We fall into categories, sure. But to really optimize the whole business we need to optimize for pockets of users. Or, we just need to set up a system that‚Äôs personalized.
Takeaway? Personalize your experiments where possible. Consider the ethical and downstream impacts of the experiment.

title: The Power of a Good Book
text:
Last night I went to a tapas style restaurant. I got 5 things. Then we opted for one more: battered cod tacos. Our taste buds rewarded us. That‚Äôs why we came.
Before that I was telling my wife, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see why my friend didn‚Äôt like the sushi. It‚Äôs fine. I just don‚Äôt know how to evaluate if something is worth it or not. Because it‚Äôs tasty, I‚Äôd recommend it‚Ä¶‚Äù This came off the heels of multiple times recently where I‚Äôve gone out with people who are foodies that criticize the meal I‚Äôm enjoying and I‚Äôm left wondering: am I a food plebe?
Experiencing this last night was poignant. The whole meal was good. Not bad. Just good.
Then came the fish tacos.
That‚Äôs how it is with reading. You need to read a lot before the good and the bad start filtering out.
And like fish tacos, maybe there are even better ones out there, but I needed this one to point me in the direction of what‚Äôs possible.
And to some degree, there‚Äôs a dulling of sensitivities. If you haven‚Äôt read good literature in a long while perhaps you assume it‚Äôs all fine and ‚Äúwhy not finish this book?‚Äù
But this year I‚Äôm trying to read many authors across many genres to tackle just that: find the books I really enjoy reading. And then ask myself, ‚Äúwhy? What was special there?‚Äù So that I know what to look for next.
Last night I began The Old Man and the Sea and it was a fish taco moment. I don‚Äôt know how I‚Äôve avoided this book so long. I‚Äôm sure I read it in like sixth grade, but does that even count? And why have I largely avoided fiction for most of my adult life? I suppose having studied something very technical in college it pushed me to stop using that side of my brain. But getting back to good books, written with such depth and creative imagination, renew me with an awareness of the dullness of business books I‚Äôve been dwelling in.



An Old Man and His Tacos


And now, for ChatGPT to answer the prompt: ‚Äúin the style of Ernest Hemingway, write three paragraphs about a man eating fish tacos‚Äù:

In the style of Ernest Hemingway, characterized by his terse and direct prose, the tale unfolds on a weathered pier stretching into the gray, restless sea. The man, solitary and rugged, sits at the edge where the wood meets the water, a plate of fish tacos beside him. His hands, calloused and strong, deftly assemble the tacos with an economy of movement that speaks of a life shaped by necessity rather than choice. The fish, freshly caught, bears the scent of the ocean, a fragrance as old as time, mingling with the sharp tang of lime and cilantro.
Around him, the world seems to hold its breath, the only sounds are the soft lapping of waves against the pilings and the distant cries of gulls, wheeling like specters in the overcast sky. He bites into a taco, the crispness of the tortilla giving way to the tender fish within, a simplicity that belies the depth of flavors. There‚Äôs a harmony here, between man and nature, a momentary peace found in the act of eating, of sustaining oneself with the bounty of the sea.
As he eats, his gaze is drawn to the horizon, where the gray of the sea blends indistinguishably with the sky. There‚Äôs a contemplation in his eyes, a man adrift in his thoughts as he is in life, finding solace in the simple pleasure of a meal. The tacos, humble yet fulfilling, become a metaphor for existence itself‚Äîuncomplicated in its components, yet profound in its satisfaction. In this moment, on this pier, the man and the sea are one, their stories intertwined in the quiet, unspoken understanding that life, in all its forms, is a series of solitary moments shared with the world.

Dang‚Ä¶‚Äúlife shaped by necessity rather than choice‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe tacos, humble yet fulfilling, become a metaphor for existence itself‚Äîuncomplicated in its components, yet profound in its satisfaction.‚Äù I‚Äôm glad Ernest is somewhere in there, AI. You may have a soul after all.
See also: Reading Ethos

title: Leaky bucket
text:
The thing about building so much so quickly is I‚Äôm starting to feel like a leaky bucket. I just know I‚Äôm letting some stuff go but need to conventrate on the most important thing.
Right now that‚Äôs switching from outlook to Google. ive decided I want everything to be in docs. Easy to share on a per client basis. Outlook was a choice for 9 months ago when I launched but I regret it.
Once I can do that then I can give more accounts to my team members so they can email people and we look more legit.
It‚Äôs all these little things that you just can‚Äôt think about when beginning. But friction comes from dozens of places. My role is to unblock my team on things they can‚Äôt do. Then I focus on stuff only I can do: sell and set up infrastructure.

I have a meeting with an apartment complex later this week. Crazy to think about what could come of that.
I have to remind myself I‚Äôm only 14 days solidly into this. I barely even know what‚Äôs going on. But people are miraculously signing up.

title: Give it time and retry
text:
A week and a half ago I wanted to shut it all down. Fire all my guys. I was burned out.
I kept the lights on though. I narrowed in. I worked on my system.
I remembered I have a lot to learn.
I‚Äôm terrified of getting rejected. But im not a sales person. I don‚Äôt have to sell anyone. I can treat the call as a free consultation.
Free is soft. It lets their guard down.
‚ÄúHey this is a free consultation. Just curious to learn what you‚Äôve done so far, bounce some ideas off you, and see if we can create some value for you. If so, we‚Äôll send you some more material and we can do a follow up call with our founder. So why are you interested in marketing services at this time? What‚Äôs working, what‚Äôs not working for you?
What have you tried in the past?
Great, our founders busy serving customers so we want to make sure we use both of your time wisely. Let‚Äôs fix a time for a 15-30 min zoom call to review anything and discuss next steps.
‚ÄúWell, calling you at random hours isn‚Äôt really conducive. You might be busy, or I might be busy. So if you‚Äôre serious, let‚Äôs commit to a time to chat and we‚Äôll set up a zoom link for 15 minutes.‚Äù
