title: Congfigurations
text:
When I walked into #Google I was so excited to learn how to code like the pros. The only coding I truly learned was the recurring daily complaint by the engineers there ‚Äúoh, I‚Äôm just moving protos again today‚Äù.
Moving protos‚Ä¶what?
Protobufs, or protos as they‚Äôre affectionately called, are a type of configuration file. And Google‚Äôs architecture is so advanced that fewer folks spend time coding and more time manipulating protos to improve the software.
Why? Because software 2.0 is impossible to automate or code. Why? The book Power and Prediction explains how future software has trillions of possible combinations of design.
#YouTube has a deep learning algorithm called Brain that has one main job: figure out the probability a person will click on a video.
On top of this, they do what all recommendation systems do: they customize the diversity of content or the categories of content. Do you want more videos similar to video X? Do you want more educational content, but very different video?
All recommendation systems operate like this: an ML model at the base and then rules and configurations to overlay on top. And the protos control the configurations. And the software engineers analyze the metrics coming from your ‚Äúwatch time‚Äù. Their job is then to manipulate the proto files to improve the system.
So when they ‚Äúmove protos‚Äù all day long, they‚Äôre just getting systems to talk to each other.
‚ÄúHow should I configure my ___ pipeline?‚Äù - asked every engineer ever. Here I take a dive into ways that I‚Äôve seen #machinelearning pipelines be configured.
https://www.bryanwhiting.com/tech/configurations-for-ml-pipelines.html



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: A tale of two price mentalities
text:
I‚Äôm thinking about Three cold calls and what I learned.
One guy hears my pitch and in 5 minutes he‚Äôs nodding his head. Then he asks, ‚ÄúWhy do you charge $650 but people in India tell me they can do it for $225?‚Äù He says he gets these calls all the time.
Another guy says, ‚ÄúI paid $250/year for my website. There‚Äôs no way I can justify your costs. I‚Äôm a simple guy and I don‚Äôt need anything fancy.‚Äù This second guy raked me over the coals an I know I shouldn‚Äôt give in but I took it as a learning experience to see what might happen.
He gets me to basically offer my services at cost, but I tell him I can only keep the deal open tonight. He responds:

That may work for me, but I always avoid making decisions under pressure, such a false urgency. Give me a few days to think about it. What do you have to lose?


I thought a lot about this. It‚Äôs an interesting question. I know from $100M Leads, This is Marketing, and Emotional Intelligence for Sales Success that when you concede, you regret it. And it‚Äôs a race to the bottom on price.
At his rates, someone would need to maintain 500 websites per year to support a family. That‚Äôs an insane amount of overhead. He should just use squarespace for $20/mo. I told him this.
The first guy hears my pitch and says, ‚Äúsee what I like about this is you‚Äôre here in San Jose. I could come see you if I want. I don‚Äôt want some random company in India that doesn‚Äôt care about me.‚Äù
The thought of ‚ÄúI could never justify this‚Äù is fascinating. It tells me this person is transaction focused. It‚Äôs quite easy to ‚Äújustify‚Äù when you consider operating your business quickly. I could get him the site today. Instead he‚Äôs taking people over the coals until he works with someone desperate enough to take his offer. The justification is: does this service get me more leads?
But he didn‚Äôt see it that way. He only saw, ‚ÄúI can get this cheaper elsewhere.‚Äù
Those two mentalities are two I‚Äôve struggled with. Most of my life I‚Äôve focused on getting things done more cheaply and feeling like I‚Äôm being robbed. Or, focusing on solving the problem.
Per Thinking, Fast and Slow we have two sides of our brain. If we lose $100 bill on the way to buy $100 worth of tickets we‚Äôre likely to buy the tickets with a new $100. If we lose two pre-purchased tickets on the way to the show, we‚Äôre likely to walk away rather than spend $100 to buy two new tickets. The cost is the same, but the mental and emotional accounting is different. This is sunk cost.
Person 1 is relationship and growth focused. They want the problem gone so they can focus on other things. They also say ‚Äúyea I could get this cheaper somewhere but there are several costs like time, energy, and dealing with India I don‚Äôt wanna deal with.‚Äù He says ‚Äúif it gets me two customers a month it‚Äôs worth it.‚Äù He‚Äôs value focused. He doesn‚Äôt think: ‚Äúcan I get this cheaper somewhere else?‚Äù
Second guy is not value focused but transaction and price focused. Maybe he does this with everyone he meets. It‚Äôll slow him down. As a home builder he could get $10000 clients from a well built website. That‚Äôs not worth $100/mo for him so he‚Äôs going to get a crappy site with no traffic (I‚Äôve built many crappy sites that don‚Äôt get traffic. Good sites require work!)
Do business with value-based customers. They grow faster. They‚Äôre deal oriented. Relationship oriented.
Don‚Äôt do business with transaction/cost-oriented customers. They‚Äôll take you up front and throughout your journey, costing far more in time and energy, which allows your momentum and hurts your growth.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: 17 appointments. What?
text:
I have a commission only cold caller. He started last Thursday and has booked one appointment per 4 hour shift. Two of them didn‚Äôt turn out to be interested (expected).
Then my full time guy joined today. He was hard to negotiate with. He wanted $5/hour. I offered him double that, but in commissions. He pushed back.
We settled on $2.5 per hour plus commissions. We went back and fourth three times.
Why was this good?
Well it showed me he knows how to negotiate. Why hire a salesperson who can‚Äôt negotiate?
Yesterday in 7 hours he booked 17 appointments.
I don‚Äôt know what to do. So I set up Calendly so he can book my calendar. And I set up zoom for zoom calls. And I integrated pipe drive.
Today I‚Äôm gonna nail my proposal PDF. Get



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: The emotional burdens
text:
The emotional burden of solving a small problem for a low-paying customer is just as great as a high paying customer. It‚Äôs just ‚Äúanother thing to do‚Äù.
I‚Äôve also gotten lost in operational minutia. I‚Äôve only called 6 people that my guy has given me. There are dozens. I need to prioritize calling people.
People are very interested the first call and then i can‚Äôt get a hold of them again. I try with different phone numbers so I don‚Äôt think they‚Äôve blocked me yet.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: The Overwhelming Chaos
text:
‚ÄúStarting a business is like chewing glass‚Äù - Elon Musk. Here‚Äôs why.
Silvermine AI took many huge steps forward. Onboarded six customers. Prepped for 5 more deals. Here‚Äôs what happens behind the scenes.
Here‚Äôs a list of everything that I did:

Migrate from Outlook to Gmail. Fix my DNs records so I don‚Äôt get flagged as spam. My company‚Äôs website crashes (it‚Äôs okay I‚Äôm gonna gut it anyway and move over to what I‚Äôm putting my customers on.)
set up an account for my web dev to build a site for my customer.
Review my web devs site. Evaluate quality. Find broken links.
Call 4 people my cold caller found. They‚Äôre all interested.
Follow up text with one. He tries grinding 95% of my margin. I let him. I regret it. Deal falls through anyway. He‚Äôs not my target customer.
post updates on Facebook. Someone I haven‚Äôt spoken too in 15 years calls me greedy. I‚Äôm working 80 hour weeks with no pay for the next three months c supporting people who are otherwise unemployed. Some people just wanna tear you down. I‚Äôve heard it spoken that when you try to do something, the people not in the arena like throwing boos. But the people on the field respect you. ‚ÄúIt is not the critic who counts.‚Äù As that quote goes. Dare bravely.
Send material to my social media manager.
Review the work she did. Get stoked. She‚Äôs crushing it. My clients like it.
Reach out to owner to ask what they want on their website. Don‚Äôt hear back. Check in next week I suppose.
Send out 6 onboarding forms. 3 don‚Äôt reply. Check back next week I suppose.
Discuss with my ads manager how to do ads. Customer asks me questions. I‚Äôm relaying info to my manager. I‚Äôm learning. Try to schedule time. Pause writing this because I realize I forgot to schedule that follow up time with my customers.
My customers are so busy they don‚Äôt have time to respond. I‚Äôm so busy trying to remember who I‚Äôve responded to.
Reach back out to 10 warm leads. People interested but too busy to respond. I send out a calendar invite just to see if that‚Äôs easier than trying to text them again. It is. The random time I picked didn‚Äôt work (as expected). They responded with a better time (amazing). I‚Äôm one step closer to helping them get the site they want. Success.
Reach out to a family member who posted on Facebook about their construction business. They knew I stated a business but didn‚Äôt know exactly what. We have an hour chat. They realize I may be able to help them. Document new lead. Follow up for Monday.
This said family member on my wife‚Äôs side is surprisingly a customer of my cousins on my side. Wild. I realize that my cousin is a chiropractor. I could potentially help him build his business. Try calling, out of office. Make a new lead in my CRM. Follow up next Wednesday.
Do an audit of a site. Send out a response. Didn‚Äôt get an answer. Decided instead of texting I‚Äôll do the same thing as above and send another cal invite. Waiting to hear back.
One of the four interested cold calls said he was super interested and to call back on Friday. I‚Äôm stoked. Then I call back Friday. He says call back in 15. I call back in 45 bc of another meeting. He silences my call and sends me straight to voicemail. I send a text. No response. Follow up one time next week before closing as a lost. People are weird. But I get it. He didn‚Äôt recognize our convo from Wednesday. He doesn‚Äôt have time to deal with this decision. I know how that goes.
third interested guy says he‚Äôll sign up next week once he gets paid. Stoked. Send reminder in CRM. Hopefully he doesn‚Äôt forget me like the Friday guy.
Fourth interested guy says to call back in the evening that very same day. He‚Äôs stoked. I call back but his daughter broke her arm just hours earlier. Going to hospital. I‚Äôm surprised he responded at all. I send him a text the next day wishing his daughter well. I call back two days later and he‚Äôs at the dentist. He appreciated my text. I choose to set up time next Tuesday. He agrees. Hope is still alive.
Pay my workers for their hard work. Realize I‚Äôm still losing money. That‚Äôs expected. im investing.
write down all the tools I‚Äôve subscribed to in the last three weeks.
Send credentials to my team so they can use these tools.
Get four audits from my SEO expert. Tell him what to improve. He sends back more content.
move content to Google drive.
Set up client folders on Google drive. Set up documents with info per client to collaborate. Have assistant help.
spend 3 hours preparing for key partner. I spent 10 the prior week. I‚Äôm excited. Call goes well.
Send material to other potential key partner. He‚Äôs excited. I‚Äôm excited. May be a few weeks or months before it‚Äôs a good time though. Keep building. Remember to follow up.
Reach out to another key partner.
A friend from high school I haven‚Äôt seen since 2008 wants to chat. He does what I do but for sales (I‚Äôm on marketing). Have a chat. He tells me he wants to send me clients. I tell him I need his help. He sets up more time on Monday to chat. Hope builds.
college friend who does a different type of SEO than me reaches out. His cousin needs help with Local SEO (my specialty). I send phone number.
Said cousin calls me within an hour. I don‚Äôt recognize the number but I pick up now. Person is from my grandma‚Äôs home town. Wild. Another small connection. Person asks me about Google business profile. I answer. They seem relieved. They ask for my services. I send a doc. Set up time to chat Tuesday.
Decline meeting with one person because I‚Äôm so busy.
Go to work because I‚Äôm not full time. Manage work‚Ä¶.
Set up asana instead of ClickUp for task management. Asana is expensive. ClickUp is free. But ClickUp is complicated. I realize $100/mo is not worth complication.
Add 6 people to asana. Track down their emails. Realize I forgot each persons hourly rate. Create an HR spreadsheet.
Add 4 people to slack. I need to get off email for internal work. Happy.
Just realized I forgot to add that friends cousin to my CRM. Pause now to add them. They‚Äôre added 3 minutes later. Had to look up their email to add to my CRM.
Realized my CRM isn‚Äôt connected to my email. Sync is broken. Reach out to customer support.
Realize after switching Gmail to Outlook that calendly and outlook are stuck to the Microsoft version of my email address. That‚Äôs weird. Fix outlook in my mobile. Fix calendly. Can now book appointments properly. Success.
Had a customer call. Chat for 30 min about next steps. Phone dies mid call. Back to real job.
realize I paid my part timer for not doing anything this week. Crap. I quickly send them their task, which was stuck in draft mode on slack. I make a note to my assistant to ensure this doesn‚Äôt slip through.
Get access to Google business profiles. Send them to my developer.
Migrate subscriptions off of an old Gmail. I‚Äôm official now. I should have everything on my @silvermineai.com domain
Add all subscriptions to my finance tracker.
Random people I haven‚Äôt spoken to in years or ever start commenting on my fb posts. I reach out to one. They have a non-profit. I suddenly want to help. I now can because I do websites. They need help with their website. I get excited about their mission.
Hopped on Facebook to post this. Realize there‚Äôs an ad about Facebook marketing. I click. The content is exactly what I‚Äôm looking for. I could probably find it online on YouTube but I buy a 2.5 hour course. Paid content is usually better than free. Not always. I say no to all upselling stuff. Inbox gets links to the course.
Chat with guy about working together on something else. Realize I didn‚Äôt text him back. Just opened my notes and sent him the thing I 95% finished.
After sending this blurb I realized I have a buddy I‚Äôve been meaning to reach out to. I do a quick audit of his Google ranking for his stores. I send off some analytics.
Three nights this week I only got 6 hours of sleep. Body fatigue.

Why am I doing this?

Support my family. I‚Äôve got 6 mouths to feed. California is a tough break for anyone trying to live here. Taxes are high. Most people are dual income. This raises housing prices.
Empower others. I find intense emotional fulfillment in helping others grow.
Grow. I‚Äôm up for new challenges. This is right up my alley.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Three cold calls
text:
Cold call 1 (follow up from Guil) - very interested. - Wants to work with me even though people are offering $225/mo
Cold call 2: Are you a small business? This person was caught off guard because I‚Äôm small and he‚Äôs been raked over by people who just take his money and don‚Äôt do anything.
Cold call 3: just wants a website. He haggles me down and I concede. I eventually say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm at my limit you have 24 hours‚Äù and he says ‚Äúwhat do you have to lose? Gimme a few days‚Äù I feel used. I feel stripped down. This isn‚Äôt worth it.
The first two people saw my value immediately - within 5 minutes. The first guy wanted me to call him back this evening. I did and he had an emergency.
I have a big client on Friday. I‚Äôve been prepping. I know how to handle them. I‚Äôm excited.
I‚Äôve got 7 clients now. Ramping up. Trying to get things working. Just excited. Crazy that Guil‚Äôs three cold calls today did so well. Very exciting.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Day two of calls
text:
Wild day. I set up Kixie and was uploading contacts as my freelance cold caller was getting rejected. We iterated on the script. Then another cold caller wanted to be more full time. So I offered her $1/hour. She worked one hour until she gave up.
No appointments. But I sent my first invoice. I‚Äôll send another invoice tomorrow. I have two confirmed customers. I‚Äôm at $270/mo revenue.
This is just the beginning.



_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: Since June 7th
text:
What have I learned since June 7th, the day I announced my marketing agency on Facebook?

There are so many entrepreneurs in my network. People building and growing. People with dreams of creating value in their own unique way. I think I‚Äôve spoken to 15 people off that one post alone.
There are people who want to work with you. You just have to let them know you‚Äôre open for business.
Creating value is about doing things that others don‚Äôt have time for, but know is important. We all have 100 things going on in our overly busy lives. It‚Äôs a relief to outsource those problems where we can.
So many ideas stall because people just forget of them. People tell me ‚ÄúI‚Äôve wanted to do this for years but other priorities have taken place‚Äù. Hiring someone can help provide a catalyst of new ideas and opportunities.
Some people are reasonably skeptical. So many scammers out there in the marketing world. I hope to make a difference. I see the opportunity for good marketing.
I‚Äôve transitioned mentally from being an individual contributor to an operator. I‚Äôve got four team members who just hammer away at tasks I send them. It‚Äôs stressful, but exciting!
Anyone using AI tools can do remarkable things. High schoolers on AI can do as much as a 5 year experienced individual. My team is remote and the tools they use make their work shine as good as I could have done it.
AI is enabling people with good ideas to provide exceptional value. I‚Äôm a software engineer by trade and being able to work with marketing AI tools is really exciting.
I‚Äôm exhausted. In the best way possible. I couldn‚Äôt do it without Veronica Rosdahl Whiting‚Äôs support.
it‚Äôs fairly easy to give a really hardworking individual a life changing amount of money for doing solid work. I paid this guy $40 for helping me organize a bunch of stuff. He said it was life changing. Super humbling to learn of the great fortunes we have in the US. I could then hire him full time as my executive assistant and he‚Äôs helping us serve our 6 new customers since June 7th.



marketing is about following up. About showing up. Reach out to everyone who likes your post. Ask them if they know anyone. Ask them if there‚Äôs some way you can help them.




_________________________   Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

title: AI News Recap
text:
Token 1.17: Deploying ML Model: Best practices feat. LLMs - Companies will have a question of what models to use: cloud based, cloud open, or internal open. - GPT: closed cloud. - Llama: open internal. - Perplexity/Mistral hosting: open cloud. - my Assumption is that open cloud will catch up. Especially when they match it with vector embeddings. No provider does both embeddings and inference as a service, which is interesting. - Thoughts on vector DBs Reddit - Dive into anything - Seems cool: Lightning AI, which allows you to do like a repl type solution but for AI. Curious how good the editor is.
The Lazy Tyranny of the Wait Calculation - by Ethan Mollick - waiting for tech to be competent to achieve your vision or hop on the train? - I think software will catch up quickly. Our ability to get to a solution faster means faster prototyping, pickier customers, but ultimately more junk. The question of product market fit will always be the question, regardless if you wait. But some ideas may be worth trying a year from now rather than doing all this stuff that will be obsolete with the next AI release. - This blog itself wouldn‚Äôt be possible without Obsidian Mobile, free GitHub repos, Working Copy App, and quarto and iOS shortcuts. so the technologies need to converge to enable certain innovations (in this case my peculiar system for how to blog online from my phone)



Dreaming of cloud solutions


GPTs won‚Äôt make you rich - by Charlie Guo - GPTs are now available. The Teams pricing is now available.
Why knowledge management is foundational to AI success - Stack Overflow - Generic old news. General principles that garbage in, garbage out.

title: AI and the Future of SaaS
text:
Reading this:

And that‚Äôs what AI should always be. A feature of your product, not your product itself. AI can be an interface to your users‚Äô data or a means of transforming that data into shapes that are more useful to your users.

ChatGPT will likely never build a todo list app that manages sending you notifications, etc. (Not until they have their own OS at least).
Focus on building AI-augmented experiences.
